publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Lisauro, Terzo, Ismena, and Aminta.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: LEt the Coach go round, wee'l walk along these Meadows:
And meet at Port again: Come my fair Sister,
These cool shades will delight ye.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Pray be merry,
The Birds sing as they meant to entertain ye,
Every thing smiles abroad: me thinks the River
(As he steals by) curles up his head, to view ye:
Every thing is in Love.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: You would have it so.
You that are fair, are easie of belief, Cosen,
The Theame slides from your Tongue.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I fair, I thank ye:
Mine's but shadow when your Sun shines by me.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: No more of this, you know your worth (Aminta)
Where are we now?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Hard by the Town (Ismena)

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Close by the Gates:

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: 'Tis a fine Ayre.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: A delicate;
The way so sweet and even, that the Coach
Would be a tumbling trouble to our pleasures,
Methinks I am very merry:

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I am sad:

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You are ever so when we entreat ye (Cosen)

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I have no reason: such a trembling here
Over my heart methinks:

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Sure you are fasting,
Or not slept well to night; some dream (Ismena)

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: My dreams are like my thoughts, honest, and innocent,
Yours are unhappy; who are these that coast us? Enter Antonio & Martin.
You told me the walk was private.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: 'Tis most commonly:

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Two proper men: it seems they have some busines,
With me none sure; I do not like their faces;
They are not of our Company:

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: No Cosen:
Lisauro, we are dog'd.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I find it (Cosen)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What handsome Lady?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, shee's very handsom.
They are handsome both,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Martin, stay we are cosened.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will go up; a woman is no wild-fire.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now by my life she is sweet: Stay good Martin,
They are of our enemies; the House of Belides,
Our mortal enemies:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let 'em be devills,
They appear so handsomly, I will go forward;
If these be enemies, I'le ne'er seek friends more.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Prethee forbear; the Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That's it (man)
That mopes me like a Gin.
'Pray ye stand off Ladies:

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: They are both our enemies: both hate us equally;
By this fair day our mortal foes.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I know'em,
And come here to affront: how they gape at us?
They shall have gaping-work.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Why your swords, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Pray ye stand you off, Cosen,
And good now leave your whistling: we are abus'd all,
Back, back I say:

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Go back.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We are no doggs Sir,
To run back on command.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Wee'l make ye run, Sir,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Having a civil charge of handsom Ladies,
We are your servants: pray ye no quarrel Gentlemen.
There's way enough for both.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Wee'l make it wider.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If you will fight arm'd, from this Saint; have at ye.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: O me unhappy, are ye Gentlemen?
Discreet, and Civil, and in open view thus?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What will men think of us? nay you may kill us;
Mercy o'me: through my petticoat; what bloody gentlemeÌ„!

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Make way through me, ye had best, and kill an innocent:
Brother, why Cosen: by this light Ile die too:
This Gentleman is temperate: be you merciful:
Alas, the Swords.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You had best run me through the belly,
'Twill be a valiant thrust.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I faint amongst ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Pray ye be not fearful; I have done (sweet Lady)
My sword's already aw'd, and shall obey ye:
I come not here to violate sweet beauty,
I bow to that.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Brother, you see this Gentleman,
This Noble Gentleman,

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Let him avoid then,
And leave our Walk.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The Lady may command Sir,
She bears an eye more dreadful then your weapon.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: What a sweet nature this man has? dear brother,
Put up your sword.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Let them put up and walk then:

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No more loud words: there's time enough before us:
For shame put up, do honour to these beauties:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Our way is this,
We will not be denyde it.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: And ours is this, we will not be cross'd in it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What ere your way is (Lady) 'tis a fair one;
And may it never meet with rude hands more,
Nor rough uncivil Tongues. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I thank ye Sir,
Indeed I thank ye nobly: A brave Enemie,
Here's a sweet temper now: This is a man (Brother)
This Gentleman's anger is so nobly seated,
That it becomes him: Yours proclaim ye Monsters.
What if he be our House-Foe? we may brag on't:
We have ne'er a friend in all our House so honourable:
I had rather from an Enemie, my Brother,
Learn worthy distances and modest difference.
Then from a race of empty friends, loud nothings:
I am hurt between ye.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: So am I, I fear too:
I am sure their swords were between my leggs; deer Cosen
Why look ye pale? where are ye hurt?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I know not,
But here me-thinks.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Unlace her gentle Cosen.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: My heart, my heart, and yet I blesse the Hurter.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Is it so dangerous?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I faint not.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Here is no blood that I find, sure 'tis inward:

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Yes, yes, 'tis inward: 'twas a subtle weapon,
The hurt not to be cur'd I fear.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: The Coach there.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: May be affright.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Aminta, 'twas a sweet one,
And yet a cruel.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Now I find the wound plain:
A wondrous handsome Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Oh no deeper:
Prethee be silent (wench) it may be thy cause.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You must be searched: the wound will rancle; Cosen
And of so sweet a nature.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Deer Aminta:
Make it not sorer.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: And on my life admires ye.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Call the Coach, Cosen.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: The Coach, the Coach.

sp.speaker: Ter,
sp.l: 'Tis ready, bring the Coach there.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Well my brave enemies, we shall yet meet ye,
And our old hate shall testifie.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: It shall (Cosen.) Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Their swords, alas, I weigh'em not (deer Friend)
The indiscretion of the Owners blunts'em;
The fury of the House affrights not me,
It spends it self in words: (Oh me Martine)
There was a two edg'd eye, a Lady carried
A weapon that no valour can avoyd,
Nor Art (the hand of Spirit) put aside.
O Friend, it broke out on me like a bullet
Wrapt in a cloud of fire: that point (Martine)
Dazled my sence, and was too subtle for me,
Shot like a Comet in my face, and wounded
(To my eternal ruine) my hearts valour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Methinks she was no such peece.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Blaspheme not Sir,
She is so far beyond weak commendation,
That impudence will blush to think ill of her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I see it not, and yet I have both eies open:
And I could judge, I know there is no beauty
Till our eies give it'em, and make'em hansom;
What's red and white, unles we do allow'em?
A green face else; and me-thinks such an other.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Peace thou leud Heretick; Thou judge of beauties?
Thou hast an excellent sense for a signe-post (Friend)
Dost thou not see? Ile swear thou art soon blind else,
As blind as ignorance; when she appear'd first
Aurora breaking in the east, and through her face,
As if the Hours and Graces had strew'd Roses,
A blush of wonder flying; when she was frighted
At our uncivil swords, didst thou not mark
How far beyond the purity of snow
The soft wind drives whitenes of innocence,
Or any thing that bears Celestial palenes,
She appear'd o'th' sodain? Didst thou see her tears
When she intreated? O thou Reprobate!
Didst thou not see those orient tears flow'd from her,
The little Worlds of Love? A sett (Martine)
Of such sanctified Beads, and a holy heart to love
I could live ever a Religious Hermite.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do beleeve a little, and yet me-thinks
She was of the lowest stature.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A rich Diamond
Set neat and deep; Natures chief Art (Martine)
Is to reserve her Modells curious,
Not cumbersome and great; and such a one
For fear she should exceed, upon her matter
Has she fram'd this; Oh 'tis a spark of beauty,
And where they appear so excellent in little,
They will but flame in great; Extention spoils'em:
Martine learn this, the narrower that our eies
Keep way unto our object, still the sweeter
That comes unto us: Great bodies are like Countries,
Discovering still, toyle and no pleasure finds'em.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A rare Cosmographer for a small Island.
Now I believe she is handsom.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Belive heartily,
Let thy belief, though long a coming, save thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: She was (certain) fair.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But heark ye (Friend Martine)
Do not believe your self too far before me,
For then you may wrong me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Who bid ye teach me?
Do you show me meat, and stitch my lips (Antonio?)
Is that fair play?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Now if thou shouldst abuse me,
And yet I know thee for an arrant Wencher,
A most immoderate thing; thou canst not love long.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A little serves my turn, I fly at all games,
But I believe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How if we never see her more?
Shee is our enemie.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why are you jealous then?
As far as I conceive she hates our whole House.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yet (good Martine)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come, come, I have mercy on ye:
You shall enjoy her in your dream (Antonio)
And I'll not hinder: though now I perswade my self.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sit with perswasion down, and you deal honestly:
I will look better on her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay, who's this, Friend?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is't not the other Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, a Letter.
She brings no challenge sure: if she do (Antonio)
I hope shee'l be a Second too; I am for her.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: A good houre Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are welcom Lady;
'Tis like our late rude passage has powr'd on us
Some reprehension.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: No, I bring no anger,
Though some deserv'd it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sure we were all too blame, Lady;
But for my part (in all humility
And with no little shame) I ask your pardons,
Indeed I wear no sword to fright sweet beauties.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You have it, and this Letter; pray ye Sir view it,
And my Commission's done.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Have ye none for me Lady?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Not at this time.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am sorry for't; I can read too.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I am glad: but Sir, to keep you in your exercise,
You may chance meet with one ill written.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thank ye,
So it be a womans, I can pick the meaning,
For likely they have but one end.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You say true Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Martine, my wishes are come home and loaden,
Loaden with brave return: most happy, happy:
I am a blessed man: where's the Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Gone, the spirit's gone: what news?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis from the Lady;
From her we saw: from that same miracle,
I know her Name now: read but these three lines;
Read with devotion, friend, the lines are holy.

sp.speaker: Martine
sp.l: I dare not chide ye in my Letter (Sir)
'Twill be too gentle: If you please to look me
In the West-street, and find a fair Stone window,
Carved with white Cupids; there Ile entertain ye:
Night and discretion guide ye.
Call me Ismena.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Give it me again: Come, come, fly, fly, I am all fire.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There may be danger.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So there is to drink
When men are thirsty, to eat hastily
When we are hungry: so there is in sleep, Friend,
Obstructions then may rise, and smother us,
We may die laughing, choked, even at devotions:
An Apoplexie, or a sodain Palsey
May strike us down.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: May be a train to catch ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then I am caught: and let Love answer for it.
'Tis not my folly, but his infamy:
And if he be adored, and dare do vild things.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well, I will go.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She is a Lady, Sir,
A Maid, I think, and where that holy spell
Is flung about me, I ne're fear a villany,
'Tis almost night: away friend.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am ready,
I think I know the house too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Then we are happy. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Did you meet him?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: And did you give my Letter?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: To what end went I?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Are ye sure it was he?
Was it that Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Do you think I was blind?
I went to seek no Carrier, nor no Midwife.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: What kind of man was he? thou maist be deceived Friend.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: A man with a nose on's face: I think he had eies too,
And hands: for sure he took it.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: What an answer?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What questions are these to one that's hot and troubled?
Do you think me a Babe? am I not able (Cosen)
At my years and discretion, to deliver
A Letter handsomly! is that such a hard thing?
Why every wafer-woman will undertake it:
A Sempsters girle, or a Taylors wife will not misse it:
A Puritane Hostesse (Cosen) would scorn these questions.
My legges are weary.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I'll make'em well again.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Are they at Supper?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Yes, and I am not well,
Nor desire no company: look out, 'tis darkish.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I see nothing yet: assure your self, Ismena,
If he be a man he will not misse.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: It may be he is modest,
And that may pull him back from seeing me;
Or has made some wild construction of my easinesse:
I blush to think what I writ.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What should ye blush at?
Blush when you act your thoughts, not when you write 'em;
Blush soft between a pair of sheets, sweet Cosen,
Though he be a curious carried Gentleman, I cannot think
He's so unnatural to leave a woman,
A young, a noble, and a beauteous woman,
Leave her in her desires: Men of this age
Are rather prone to come before they are sent for.
Hark, I hear somthing: up to th'Chamber, Cosen,
You may spoil all else.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Let me see, they are Gentlemen;
It may be they.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: They are they: get ye up,
And like a Land-star draw him.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I am shamefac'd. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This is the street.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am looking for the house:
Close, close, pray ye close here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No, this is a Merchants;
I know the man well:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And this a Pothecaries: I have lain here many times.
For a loosenes in my Hilts.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Have ye not past it?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No sure:
There is no house of mark that we have scaped yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What place is this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Speak softer: 'may be spies;
If any, this, a goodly window too,
carv'd far above, that I perceive: 'tis dark,
But she has such a lustre.

div.stage: Enter Ismena and Aminta above with a Taper.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes Martine,
So radiant she appears.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Else we may misse, Sir:
The night growes vengeance black, 'pray heaven she shine clear:
Hark, hark, a window, and a candle too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Step close, 'tis she: I see the cloud disperse,
And now the beautious Planet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Hah, 'tis indeed,
Now by the soul of love a divine Creature.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Sir, Sir,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Most blessed Lady.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: 'Pray ye stand out.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You need not fear, there's no body now stirring.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Beyond his commendation I am taken,
Infinite strangely taken.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I love that Gentleman,
Methinks he has a dainty nimble body:
I love him heartily.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: 'Tis the right Gentleman:
But what to say to him, Sir.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Speak.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I wait still,
And will do till I grow an other Pillar,
To propt this house, so it please you.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Speak softly,
And 'pray ye speak truly too.

sp.speaker: Ant,
sp.l: I never lyde, Lady.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: And don't think me impudent to ask ye,
I know ye are an Enemie, speak low,
But I would make ye a friend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am friend to beauty;
Ther's no handsomnesse I dare be foe too.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Are ye married?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Are ye betrothed?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No, neither.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Indeed (fair Sir.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Indeed (fair sweet) I am not.
Most beauteous Virgin, I am free as you are.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: That may be Sir, then ye are miserable,
For I am bound.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Happy the bonds that hold ye;
Or do you put them on your self for pleasure?
Sure they be sweeter far then libertie:
There is no blessednesse but in such bondage:
Give me that freedom (Madam) I beseech ye,
(Since you have question'd me so cunningly)
To ask you whom you are bound to, he must be certain
More then humane, that bounds in such a beauty:
Happy that happy chain, such links are heavenly.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Pray ye do not mock me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Pray ye (Lady) tell me.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Will ye beleeve, and will ye keep it to ye?
And not scorn what I speak?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I dare not (Madam)
As Oracle what you say, I dare swear to.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I'll set the candle by: for I shall blush now;
Fy, how it doubles in my mouth? it must out,
'Tis you I am bound to.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Speak that word again,
I understand ye not.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: 'Tis you I am bound to.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here is another gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: 'Tis you Sir.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: He may belov'd too.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not by thee, first curse me.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: And if I knew your name.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Antonio (Madam)

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.p: Antonio, take this kisse, 'tis you I am bound to.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And when I set ye free, may heaven forsake me, Ismena.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Yes, now I perceive ye love me,
You have learnd my name.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hear but some vows I make to ye:
Hear but the protestations of a true love.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: No, no, not now: vowes should be cheerful things,
Done in the cleerest light, and noblest testimony:
No vow (deer Sir) tye not my fair belief
To such strict termes: those men have broken credits,
Loose and dismembred faiths (my deer Antonio)
That splinter'em with vows: am I not too bold?
Correct me when you please.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I had rather hear ye,
For so sweet Musick never struck mine eares yet:
Will you believe now?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am yours.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Speak lowder,
If ye answer the Priest so low, you will lose your wedding

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Would I might speak, I would holloa.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Take my heart,
And if it be not firm and honest to you,
Heaven.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Peace, no more: I'll keep your heart, and credit it.
Keep you your word: when will you come again (Friend?)
For this time we have wooed indifferently,
I would fain see ye, when I dare be bolder.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why any night: onely (deer noble Mistris)
Pardon three daies: my Uncle Julio
Has bound me to attend him upon promise,
Upon expectation too: we have rare sports there,
Rare Countrey sports, I would you could but see'em.
Dare ye so honour me?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I dare not be there,
You know I dare not, no, I must not (friend)
Where I may come with honourable freedom:
Alas, I am ill too; wee in love.

sp.speaker: Ant,
sp.l: You flowt me.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Trust me I do not: I speak truth, I am sickly,
And am in Love: but you must be Physician.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll make a plaister of my best affection.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Be gone, we have supp'd, I hear the people stir,
Take my best wishes: give me no cause (Antonio)
To curse this hapyy night.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll lose my life first,
A thousand kisses.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Take ten thousand back again.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am dumb with admiration: shall we goe Sir? Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Dost thou know his Uncle?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: No, but I can ask, Cosen.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I'll tell thee more of that, come let's to bed both,
And give me handsom dreams, Love, I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: 'Has given ye a handsom subject.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Pluck to the windows. Exeunt.
Six Chaires placed at the Arras.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: The thundring Seas, whose watry fire washes
The whiting mops:
The gentle Whale whose feet so fell
Flies ore the Mountains tops. within Franio.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Boy.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: The thundring.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why boy Bustofa.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Here I am, the gentle whale. Ent. Franio.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Oh, are you here Sir? where's your sister?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: The gentle whale flies ore the mountain tops.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Where's your sister (man)

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Washes the whiting-Mops.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: Thou ly'st, she has none to wash mops?
The boy is half way out of his wits, sure:
Sirrha, who am I?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: The thundring Seas.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Mad, stark mad.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Will you not give a man leave to con?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, and fesse too, ere I have done with you Sirrha,
Am I your father?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: The question is too hard for a child, ask me any thing
That I have learn'd, and I'll answer you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Is that a hard question? Sirrha, am not I your Father?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: If I had my mother-wit I could tell you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Are you a thief?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: So far forth as the son of a Miller.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Will you be hang'd?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Let it go by eldership. The gentle Whale.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sirrha, lay by your foolish study there,
And beat your brains about your owne affairs: orâ€”

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I thank you; you'ld have me goe under the sails
And beat my brains about your mill? a naturall
Father you are.â€”

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I charge you go not to the sports to day:
Last night I gave you leave, now I recant.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Is the wind turn'd since last night?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Marry is it Sir, go no farther then my Mill;
There's my command upon you.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I may go round about then as your Mill does?
I will see your Mill gelded, and his Stones fryde in steaks,
Ere I deceive the Countrey so: have I not my part to study?
How shall the sports go forward, if I be not there?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: They'll want their fool indeed, if thou bee'st not there.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Consider that, and go your self.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I have fears (Sir) that I cannot utter,
You go not, nor your Sister: there's my charge.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: The price of your golden thumb cannot hold me.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I, this was sport that I have tightly lov'd,
I could have kept company with the Hounds.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: You are fit for no other company yet.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Run with the Hare; and bin in the whore's tayl 'y faith:

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: That was before I was born, Ent. Otrante and Gerasto.
I did ever mistrust I was a Bastard,
Because Lapis is in the singular number with me.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Leave thou that gun (Gerasto) and chase here,
Do thou but follow it with my desires,
Thou'lt not return home emptie.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I am prepard
(My Lord) wjth advantages: and see
Yonder's the subject I must work upon:

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Her Brother? 'tis, methinks it should be easie:
That grosse compound cannot but diffuse
The soul in such a latitude of ease,
As to make dull her faculties, and lazie:
What wit above the least can be in him,
That Reason ties together?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: I have prov'd it, Sir,
And know the depth of it: I have the way
To make him follow me a hackney-pace,
With all that flesh about him; yes, and dragge
His Sister after him: This baytes the old one,
Rid you him, and leave me to the other. Exit

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: 'Tis well: O Franio, the good day to you;
You were not wont to hear this musick standing:
The Beagle and the Bugle ye have lov'd,
In the first rank of Huntsmen.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: The doggs cry out of him now.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Sirrha, leave your barking, I'll bite you else:

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Curre, Curre.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Slave, do'st call me dog?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Oh fie Sir, he speaks Latine to you,
He would know why you'll bite him.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Responde cur; You see his understanding (my Lord)

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I shall have a time to curry you for this:
But (my Lord) to answer you, the daies have been
I must have footed it before this Horn-pipe,
Though I had hazarded my Mill a fire,
And let the stones grinde empty: but those dancings
Are done with me: I have good will to it still.
And that's the best I can do.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Come, come, you shall be hors'd:
Your company deserves him, though you kil him,
Run him blind, I care not.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Hee'll do't o'purpose (my Lord) to bring him up to the Mill.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Do not tempt me too far (my Lord)

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: There's a foot i'th' stirrop: I'll not leave you now:
You shall see the Game fall once again:

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Well (my Lord) I'll make ready my leggs for you,
And try'em once a horsback: sirra: my charge, keep it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Yes, when you pare down your dish for conscience sake.
When your thumb's coyn'd into bone & legalis,
When you are a true man-Miller.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: What's the matter Bustofa?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: My Lord; if you have ere a drunken Jade that has the staggers,
That will fall twice the height of our Mill with him: set him
O'th' back on him: a galled Jennet that will winch him out o' the
Saddle, and breake one on's necks, or a shank of him (there was
A fool going that way, but the Asse had better lucke;)
Or one of your brave Barbaries, that would passe the Straites, and run
Into his owne Countrey with him; the first Moor he met, would
Cut his throat for Complexions sake: there's as deadly feud between
A Moor and a Miller, as between black and white.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Fie, fie, this is unnaturall Bustofa,
Unlesse on some strong cause.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Be Judge (my Lord)
I am studied in my part: the Julian-Feast is to day: the Countrey
Expects me; I speak all the dumb shews: my sister chosen for
A Nimp. The gentle Whale whose feet so fell: Cry mercy,
That was some of my part: But his charge is to keep the Mill,
And disappoint the Revels.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.p: Indeed, there it speaks shrewdly for thee; the Country expecting.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I, and for mine own grace too.

sp.speaker: Ot.
sp.l: Yes, and being studied too: and the main Speaker too.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: The main? why all my Speech lies in the main,
And the dry ground together: The thundring seas, whose, &c.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Nay, then thou must go, thou'lt be much condemn'd else.
But then o'th' other side, obedience.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Obedience?
But speak your conscience now (my Lord)
Am not I past asking blessing at these yeers?
Speak as you'r a Lord, if you had a Miller to your father.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I must yeeld to you (Bustofa), your reasons
Are so strong, I cannot contradict: This I think,
If you go, your sister ought to go along with you.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: There I stumble now: shee is not at age.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Why? shee's fifteen, and upwards.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Thereabouts.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: That's womans ripe age; as full as thou art
At one and twenty: shee's manable, is she not?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I think not: poor heart, she was never tryde in my conscience.
'Tis a coy thing; she will not kisse you a clown, not if he
Would kisse her.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: What man?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Not if he would kisse her, I say.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Oh, 'twas cleanlier then I expected: well Sir.
I'll leave you to your own, but my opinion is,
You may take her along: this is half way:
The rest (Gerasto) and I hunt my prey.â€” Exit.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Away with the old Miller (my Lord) and the mill Strikes sail presently.

div.stage: Enter Pedro, with Gerasto blind, singing.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Come follow me (you Country-Lasses)
And you shall see such sport as passes:
You shall dance, and I will sing;
Pedro hee shall rub the string:
Each shall have a loos-bodied gown
Of green; and laugh till you lie down.
Come follow me, come follow, &c.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: O sweet Diego, the sweetest Diego, stay: Sister Florimell.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What's that, Brother?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Didst not hear Diego? Hear him, and thou'lt be ravish'd.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I have heard him sing, yet unravish'd, Brother.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: You had the better luck (Sister.) I was ravish'd
By mine own consent: Come away: for the Sports.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I have the fear of a Father on me (Brother.)

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Out: the theef is as safe as in his mill; hee's hunting with our
Great Land-lord, the Don Otrante. Strike up Diego.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: But say he return before us, Where's our excuse?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Strike up Diego. Hast no strings to thy apron?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Well, the fault lie upon your head (Brother).

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.l: My faults never mount so high (girl) they rise but to
My middle at most. Strike up Diego.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Follow me by the ear, I'll lead thee on (Bustofa) and
Pretty Florimell thy Sister: oh that I could see her.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Oh Diego, there's two pities upon thee; great pitie thou art blinde;
And as great a pitie thou canst not see.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You shall have Crowns of Roses, Daysies,
Buds, where the honey-maker gazes:
You shall taste the golden thighs,
Such as in wax-Chamber lies.
What fruit please you, taste, freely pull,
Till you have all your bellies full.
Come follow me, &c.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: O Diego, the Don was not so sweet when hee perfum'd the Steeple. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Secunda.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why, how now (Friend) thou art not lost agen?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Not lost? why, all the world's a wildernesse:
Some places peopled more by braver beasts
Then others are: But faces, faces (man)
May a man be caught with faces?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Without wonder.
'Tis odds against him: May not a good face
Lead a man about by the nose? 'las,
The nose is but a part against the whole.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But is it possible that two faces
Should be so twin'd in form, complexion,
Figure, aspect? that neither wen, nor mole,
The table of the brow, the eyes lustre,
The lips cherry; neither the blush nor smile
Should give the one distinction from the other?
Do's Nature work in molds?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Altogether.
We are all one mold, one dust.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thy reason's moldie.
I speak from the Form, thou the Matter.
Why? was't not ever one of Natures Glories,
Nay, her great peece of wonder, that amongst
So many millions millons of her works
Shee left the eye distinction, to cull out
The one from other; yet all one name, the face?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You must compare 'em by some other part
Of the body, if the face cannot do't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Didst ask her name?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, and who gave it her,
And what they promis'd more, besides a spoon,
And what Apostles picture; she is christend too,
In token wherefore she is call'd Isabella,
The daughter of a Country plow-swain by:
If this be not true, shee lyes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: She cannot;
It would be seen a blister on her lip,
Should falshod touch it, it is so tender:
Had her name held, 't had been Ismenia,
And not another of her name.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Shall I speak?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, if thou'lt speak truth: Is she not wondrous like?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: As two garments of the same fashion,
Cut from the same piece: yet if any excell,
This has the first; and in my judgement 'tis so.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis my opinion.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Were it the face
Where mine eye should dwell, I would please both
With this, as soon as one with the other.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And yet the other is the case of this.
Had I not look'd upon Ismenia,
I nere had staid beyond good-morrows time
In view of this.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Would I could leave him here,
'Twere a free passage to Ismenia:
I must now blow, as to put out the fire
Yet kindle't more. You not consider Sir,
The great disparitie is in their bloods,
Estate and fortunes: there's the rich beauty
Which this poor homelinesse is not endow'd with;
There's difference enough.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The least of all.
Equalitie is no rule in Loves Grammar:
That sole unhappinesse is left to Princes
To marry blood: we are free dsposers,
And have the power to equalize their bloods
Up to our own; wee cannot keep it back,
'Tis a due debt from us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I Sir, had you
No Father nor Unkle, nor such hinderers,
You might do with your self at your pleasure;
But as it is.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: As it is; 'tis nothing:
Their powers will come too late, to give me back
The yesterday I lost.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Indeed, to say sooth,
Your opposition from the other part
Is of more force; there you run the hazzard
Of every hour a life, had you supply;
You meet your deerest enemy in love
With all his hate about him: 'T will be more hard
For your Ismenia to come home to you,
Then you to go to Country Isabell. Enter Julio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tush; 'tis not fear removes me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No more: your Unkle.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh, the good hour upon you Gentlemen:
Welcome Nephew; Speak it to your friend Sir,
It may be happier receiv'd from you,
In his acceptance.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I made bold, Uncle,
To do it before; and I think he beleeves it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Twas never doubted, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Here are sports (Dons)
That you must look on with a loving eye,
And without Censure, 'lesse it be giving
My country neighbours loves their yeerly offrings
That must not be refus'd; though't be more pain
To the Spectator, then the painfull Actor,
'Twill abide no more test then the tinsell
Wee clad our Masks in for an hours wearing,
Or the Livory lace sometimes on the cloaks
Of a great Dons Followers: I speak no further
Then our own Country, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For my part, Sir,
The more absurd, 't shalbe the better welcom.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You'll find the guest you look for: I heard Cousen,
You were at Toledo th'other day.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Not late, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O fie! must I be plainer? You chang'd the point
With Tirso and Lisauro, two of the Stock
Of our Antagonists, the Belides.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A meer proffer, Sir; the prevention
Was quick with us: we had done somewhat else:
This Gentleman was ingag'd in 't.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I am
The enemie to his foe for it: that wild-fire
Will crave more then fair water, to quench it
I suspect. Whence it will come I know not.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I was about a gentle reconcilement,
But I do fear I shall goe back agen.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Come, come; The Sports are coming on us:
Nay, I have more guests to grace it: Welcome
Don Gostanco, Giraldo, Philippo: Seat, seat all. Musick.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Love is little, and therefore I present him, Enter a Cupid.
Love is a fire, therefore you may lament him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas poor Love, who are they that can quench him?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He 's not without those members, fear him not.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Love shoots, therefore I bear his bow about.
And Love is blind, therefore my eyes are out.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I never heard Love give reason for what he did before.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: Let such as can see, see such as cannot: behold,
Our goddesses all three strive for the ball of gold:
And here fair Paris comes, the hopefull youth of Troy,
Queen Hecub's darling-son, King Priams onely joy.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Is this Paris? I should have taken him for Hector rather.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Paris at this time: Pray you hold your prating.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Paris can be angry.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh, at this time
You must pardon him; he comes as a Judge.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: â€” Mercy on all that looks upon him, say I.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: The thundring seas whose watry fire washes the whiting-Mops,
The gentle Whale, whose feet so fell, flies ore the mountain tops.
No roares so fierce, no throats so deep, no howls can bring such fears
As Paris can, if Garden from he call his Dogs and Bears.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I, those they were that I feard all this while.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Yes Jack-an-Apes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I thank you, good Paris.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: You may hold your peace, and stand further out o'th' way then:
The lines will fall where they light,
Yes Jack-an-Apes, he hath to sports, and faces make like mirth,
Whilst bellowing buls, the horned beasts, do tosse from ground to earth:
Bloud Bear there is, as Cupid blind.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That Bear would be whip'd for losing of his eyes.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Be whipped man may see,
But we present no such content, but Nimps such as they be.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: These are long lines.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Can you blame him, leading Buls & Bears in 'em?

div.stage: Enter Shepherd singing, with Ismena, Aminta, Florimell, (as Juno, Pallas, Venus,) and 3 Nymphs attending.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Go Cupid blind, conduct the dumb, for Ladies must not speak here:
Let shepherds sing with dancing feet, and cords of musick break here. Song.
Now Ladies fight, with heels so light, by lot your luck must fall,
Where Paris please, to do you ease, and give the golden Ball. Dance.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: If you plaid Paris now Antonio, where would you bestow it?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I prethee, Friend,
Take the full freedome of thought, but no words.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Protest there's a third, which by her habit
Should personate Venus, and by consequence
Of the Story, receive the honours prize:
And were I a Paris, there it should be.
Doe you note her?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No; mine eye is so fixed,
I cannot move it.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.l: The dance is ended; Now to judgment Paris.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Here Juno, here: but stay, I do espy
A pretty gleeke comming from Pallas eye:
Here Pallas, here: yet stay agen: methinks
I see the eye of lovely Venus winks:
Oh close them both: shut in those golden eyne,
And I will kisse those sweet blind cheeks of thine.
Juno is angry: yes, and Pallas frowns,
Would Paris now were gone from Ida's-downe.
They both are fair, but Venus has the Mole,
The fairest hair, and sweetest dimple hole:
To her, or her, or her, or her, or neither;
Can one man please three Ladies altogether?
No, take it Venus, tosse it at thy pleasure,
Thou art the lovers friend beyond his measure.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Paris has done what man can do, pleas'd one,
Who can do more? Enter Gerasto, (as Mars)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay, here's another person.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Come lovely Venus, leave this lower Orbe,
And mount with Mars, up to his glorious Spheare.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: How now, what's he:

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I'm ignorant what to do, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Thy silver-yoke of Doves are in the Team,
And thou shalt fly through Apollo's Beam:
I'le see thee seated in thy golden Throne,
And hold with Mars a sweet conjunction. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Ha? what follows this? has carried away my sister Venus:
He never rehears'd his part with me before.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What follows now Prince Paris?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Hue and cry, I think Sir this is Venus voice,
Mine owne sister Florinells.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What is there some Tragick-Act behind?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: No, no, altogether Comical; Mars and Venus
Are in the old conjunction it seems.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis very improper then, for Venus
Never cryes out when she conjoynes with Mars.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: That's true indeed: they are out of their parts sure,
It may be 'tis the Book-holders fault: Ile go see.â€” Exit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How like you our Countrey Revells, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: All Gent.
sp.l: Oh, they commend themselves, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Me-thinks now
Juno and Minerva should take revenge on Paris,
It cannot end without it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I did expect
Insteed of Mars, the Storm-Gaoler Eolus,
And Juno proffring her Deiopeia
As satisfaction to the blustring god,
To send his Tossers forth.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: It may so follow,
Lets not prejudicate the History. Enter Bustofa.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Oh, oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: So, here's a Passion towards.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Help, help, if you be Gentlemen; my Sister,
My Venus; shee's stolne away.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The story changes from our expectation,

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Help, my father the Miller will hang me els: god Mars
Is a bawdy Villain: he said she should ride upon Doves:
Shee's horss'd, shee's horss'd whether she will or no.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sure I think hee's serious.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: She's horss'd upon a double Gelding, and a Stone-horse in the breech
Of her: the poor wench cries help, and I cry help, & none
Of you will help.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Speak, is it the show, or dost thou bawle?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: A pox on the Ball: my Sister bawls, and I bawl:
Either bridle horse and follow, or give me a halter
To hang my self: I cannot run so fast as a hogge.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Wie follow me, I'le fill the Countrey with pursuit
But I will find the Thief: my House thus abus'd?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: 'Tis my house that's abus'd, the Sister of my flesh and blood: oh, oh. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1. Wench.
sp.p: Tis time we all shift for our selves if this be serious.

sp.l: However I'le be gone.
And I. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You need not fright your beauties pretty souls,
With the least pale complexion of a fear.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Juno has better courage: and Minerva more discreet.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Alas my courage was so counterfeit
It might have been struck from me with a feather,
Juno ne'er had so weak a presenter.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Sure I was ne'er the wiser for Minerva,
That I find yet about me.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: My dwelling, Sir?
'Tis a poor Yeomans roof, scarce a league off,
That never sham'd me yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Your gentle pardon:
I vow my erring eyes had almost cast you
For one of the most mortal Enemies
That our Family has.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I'me forty Sir,
I am so like your foe: 'twere fit I hasted
From your offended sight.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Oh, mistake not,
It was my error, and I do confesse it:
You'l not beleeve your welcome; nor can I speak it;
But there's my friend can tell you, pray hear him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Shall I tell her Sir? I'me glad of the employment.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A kinswoman to that beauty:

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: A kin to her, Sir,
But nothing to her Beauty.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Do not wrong it, 'tis not far behind her.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Her hinder parts are not far off, indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let me but kisse you with his ardour now,
You shall feel how he loves you.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Oh forbear:
'Tis not the fashion with us, but would you
Perswade me that he loves me?

sp.speaker: Mar,
sp.l: I'le warrant you
He dies in't: and that were witnes enough on't.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Love me Sir? can you tell me for what reason?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Fy, will ye ask me that which you have about you?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I know nothing Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let him find it then;
He constantly beleeves you have the thing
That he must love you for: much is apparent,
A sweet and lovely beauty.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: So Sir; Pray you
Show me one thing: Did he nere love before?
(I know you are his bosome-Counsellor)
Nay then I see your answer is not ready:
I'le not beleeve you if you study farther.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Shall I speak truth to you?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Or speak no more.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There was a smile thrown at him, from a Lady
Whose deserts might buy him treble, and lately
He receiv'd it, and I know where he lost it,
In this face of yours: I know his heart's within you.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: May I know her name?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: In your ear you may
With vow of silence.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Hee'l not give over Sir:
If he speak for you, hee'l sure speed for you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But that's not the answer to my question.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You are the first in my virgin-conscence
That ere spoke Love to her: oh, my heart!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How doe you?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Nothing Sir: but would I had a better face.
How well yoor pulse beats.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Healthfully, does it not?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: It thumps prettily, me thinks.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Alack, I hear it
With much pitie: how great is your fault too,
In wrong to the good Lady?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You forget
The difficult passage hee has to her,
A hell of feud's between the Families.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: and that has often Love wrought by advantage
To peacefull reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There impossible.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: This way 'tis worser; 't may seed again in her
Unto another generation:
For where (poor Lady) is her satisfaction?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It comes in me; to be truth, I love her
(I'll go no farther for comparison)
As deer as hee loves you.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: How if shee love not?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Tush: be that my pains: You know not what art
I have those wayes.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Beshrow you, you have practis'd upon me,
Well, speed me here, and you with your Ismenia.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Go, the condition's drawn, ready dated,
There wants but your hand to 't.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Truly you have taken great pains, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A friendly part, no more (sweet Beuty.)

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: They are happy, Sir, have such friends as you are.
But do you know you have done well in this?
How will his Allyes receive it? shee (though I say't)
Is of no better Blood then I am.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There I leave it, I'm at farthest that way.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: You shall extend your vows no larger now.
My heart calls you mine own: and that's enough.
Reason, I know, would have all yet conceal'd.
I shall not leave you unsaluted long
Either by pen or person.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You may discourse
With me, when you think y'are alone, I shall
Be present with you.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Come Cosen, will you walk?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Alas, I was ready long since: in conscience
You would with better will yet stay behind.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Oh Love, I never thought thou'dst bin so blind.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You'll answer this Sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If ere 't be spoke on: Enter Julio.
I purpose not to propound the question.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis true the poor knave said: some Ravisher,
Some of Lusts Blood-hounds have seiz'd upon her:
The Girle is hurried, as the divell were with 'em
And help'd their speed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It may be not so ill, Sir.
A well prepared Lover may do as much
In hot blood as this, and perform't honestly.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What? steale away a virgin 'gainst her will?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It may be any mans case; despise nothing:
And that's a thiefe of a good quality,
Most commonly hee brings his theft home again,
Though with a little shame.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: There's a charge by 't
Faln upon mee: Paris (the Millers son)
Her brother, dares not venture home again
Till better tidings follow of his sister.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Y'are the more beholding to the mischance, Sir:
Had I gone a Boot-haling, I should as soon
Have stolne him, as his sister: Marry then,
To render him back in the same plight he is
May be costly: his flesh is not maintain'd with little.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I think the poor knave will pine away,
Hee cries all to be pitied yonder.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray you Sir, let's go see him: I should laugh
To see him cry sure.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Well, you are merry, Sir.
Antonio, keep this charge; I have fears
Move me to lay it on you: Pray forbear
The wayes of your enemies, the Bellides.
I have reason for my Injunction, Sir. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Aminta (as a Page with a Letter.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To me, Sir? from whom?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: A friend, I dare vow, Sir.
Though on the enemies part: the Ladie Ismenia.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Take heed: blush not too deep: let me advise you
In your Answer, 't must be done heedfully.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I should not see a masculine in peace
Out of that house.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Alas: I' am a child, Sir,
Your hates cannot last till I wear a sword.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Await me for your answer.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Hee must see her,
To manifest his shame: 'tis my advantage;
While our blood 's under us, wee keep above:
But then we fall when we do fall in love. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Prima.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: My Lord, my Lord, your house hath injur'd me,
Rob'd me of all the joyes I had on earth.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Where wert thou brought up (fellow)?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: In a Mill.
You may perceive it by my loud exclaims,
Which must rise higher yet.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Obstreperous Carle.
If thy throats tempest could ore-turn my house,
What satisfaction were it for thy child?
Turn thee the right way to thy journies end.
Wilt have her where she is not?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Here was she lost,
And here must I begin my footing after;
From whence, untill I meet a pow'r to punish,
I will not rest: You are not quick to grief,
Your hearing 's a dead sense. Were yours the losse,
Had you a daughter stoln, perhaps be-whor'd.
(For to what other end should come the thiefe)?
You'ld play the Miller then, be loud and high.
But being not a sorrow of your own,
You have no help nor pitie for another,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh, thou hast op'd a sluce was long shut up,
And let a flood of grief in; a buried grief
Thy voice hath wak'd again: a grief as old
As likely t'is, thy child is; friend; I tell thee,
I did once lose a daughter.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Did you Sir?
Beseech you then, how did you bear her losse?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: With thy grief trebled,

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: But was she stolne from you?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Yes, by devouring theeves, from whom cannot
Ever returne a satisfaction:
The wild beasts had her in her swathing clothes.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Oh much good do'em with her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Away tough churle.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Why, she was better eaten then my child,
Better by beasts then beastly men devoured,
They took away a life, no honour from her:
Those beasts might make a Saint of her, but these
Will make my child a devil: but was she, Sir,
Your onely daughter?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I ne'r had other (Friend)

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: Where are you (man?) your busines lies not here,
Your daughter's in the Pownd, I have found where.
'Twill cost you deer her freedom.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I'll break it down,
And free her without pay:
Horse-locks nor chains shall hold her from me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I'll take this relief,
I now have time to speak alone with grief. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How? my Land-lord? hee's Lord of my Lands
But not my Cattel: I'll have her again (Gill)

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: You are not mad upon the sudden now.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.l: No Gill, I have been mad these five hours:
I'll sell my Mill, and buy a Roring,
I'll batter down his house, and make a Stewes on't,

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Will you gather up your wits a little
And hear me? the King's neer by in progresse,
Here I have got our supplication drawn,
And there's the way to help us.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Give it me (Gill,)
I will not fear to give it to the King:
To his own hands (God blesse him) will I give it,
And he shall set the Law upon their shoulders,
And hang 'em all that had a hand in it.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Where's your Son?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: He shall be hang'd in flotches:
The dogs shall eat him in Lent, there's Cats-meat
And Dogs-meat enough about him.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Sure the poor girle is the Counts whore by this time.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: If she be the Counts whore, the whores Count
Shall pay for it: He shall pay for a new Maiden-head.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: You are so violous: this I'm resolv'd,
If she be a whore once, I'll renounce her,
You know, if every man had his right,
She's none of our child, but a meer foundling,
(And I can guesse the owner for a need too)
We have but fosterd her.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Gill, no more of that,
I'll cut your tongue out if you tell those tales.
Hark, hark, these Toaters tell us the King's coming:
Get you gone; I'll see if I can find him. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Lisauro, Tersa, Pedro and Moncado.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Do's the King remove to day?

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: So saies the Harbengers,
And keeps his way on to Valentia,
There ends the progresse.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: He hunts this morning Gentlemen,
And dines i'th' fields: the Court is all in readinesse.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Pedro, did you send for this Tailor? or you Moncado?
This light french-demi-launce that follows us,

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: No, I assure ye on my word, I am guiltlesse,
I owe him too much to be inward with him.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I am not quit I am sure: there is a reckoning
Of some four scarlet cloaks, and two lac'd suits
Hangs on the file still, like a fearful Comet
Makes me keep off.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I am in too Gentlemen,
I thank his faith, for a matter of three hundred.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: And I for two, what a devil makes he this way?
I do not love to see my sins before me.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: 'Tis the vacation, and these things break out
To see the Court, and glory in their debtors.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: What do you call him for? I never love
To remember their names that I owe money to,
'Tis not gentill, I shun'em like the plague ever.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: His name's Vertigo: hold your heads, and wonder,
A French-man, and a founder of new fashions:
The Revolutions of all shapes and habits
Run madding through his brains. Ent. Vertigo.

sp.speaker: Monc.
sp.l: He is very brave.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: The shreds of what he steals from us beleeve it,
Makes him a mighty man: he comes, have at ye.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Save ye together, my sweet Gentlemen,
I have been lookingâ€”

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Not for money Sir?
You know the hard time.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Pardon me sweet (Signior)
Good faith the least thought in my heart, your love Gentlemen,
Your love's enough for me: Money? hang money:
Let me preserve your love.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Yes marry shall ye,
And we our credit, you would see the Court?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: He shall see every place.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Shall I i'faith Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: The Cellar, and the Buttry, and the Kitchin,
The Pastry, and the Pantry.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: I, and taste too
Of every Office: and be free of all too:
That he may say when he comes home in glory,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: And I will say, i'faith, and say it openly,
And say it home too: Shall I see the King also?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Shalt see him every day: shalt see the Ladies
In their French clothes: shalt ride a hunting with him,
Shalt have a Mistris too: we must fool hansomly
To keep him in belief, we honour him,
He may call on us else.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: A pox upon him.
Let him call at home in's owne house for salt butter,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: And when the King puts on a new suit.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Thou shalt see it first,
And desect his dublets, that thou maist be perfect.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: The Wardrobe I would fain view, Gentlemen,
Fain come to see the Wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Thou shalt see it,
And see the secret of it, dive into it:
Sleep in the Wardrobe, and have Revelations
Of fashions five yeer hence.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Ye honour me;
Ye infinitely honour me.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Any thing i'th' Court Sir,
Or within the compasse of a Courtier,

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: My wife shall give ye thanks.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: You shall see any thing,
The privatst place, the stool, and where 'tis emptied.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Ye make me blush, ye pour your bounties, Gentlemen,
In such abundance.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: I will show thee presently
The order that the King keeps when he comes
To open view; that thou maist tell thy Neighbours
Over a shoulder of mutton, thou hast seen somthing,
Nay, thou shalt present the King for this time.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Nay, I pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: That thou maist know what State there do's belong to it;
Stand there I say, and put on a sad countenance,
Mingled with height: be cover'd, and reserved;
Move like the Sun, by soft degrees, and glorious,
Into your order (Gentlemen) uncover'd,
The King appears; Wee'l sport with you a while Sir,
I am sure you are merry with us all the year long (Tailor)
Move softer still, keep in that fencing leg; Monsieur,
Turne to no side.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: What's this that appears to him?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: 'Has a petition, and he looks most lamentably,
Mistake him, and we are made.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This is the King sure,
The glorious King, I know him by his gay clothes.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Now bear your self that you may say hereafter.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I have recover'd breath, I'll speak unto him presently,
May it please your gracious majesty to consider
A poor mans case?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What's your will Sir?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: You must accept, and read it.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: The Tailor will run mad upon my life for't.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: How he mumps and bridles: he will ne'er cut clothes again.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: And what's your grief?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: He speaks i'th' nose like his goose.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I pray you read there; I am abus'd, and frumpt Sir,
By a great man that may do ill by authority;
Poor honest men are hang'd for doing lesse Sir,
My child is stolne, the Count Otrante stole her;
A pretty child she is, although I say it,
A hansom mother, he means to make a whore of her,
A silken whore, his knaves have filch'd her from me;
He keeps lewd knaves, that do him beastly offices:
I kneel for Justice. Shall I have it Sir?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What Pageant's this?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: The King:
Tailor, stand off, here ends your apparition:
Miller, turn round, and there addresse your paper,
There, there's the King indeed.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: May it please your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why didst thou kneel to that fellow?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: In good faith Sir,
I thought he had been a King he was so gallant:
There's none here wears such gold.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: So foolishly,
You have golden busines sure; because I am homely
Clad, in no glittring suit, I'am not look'd on:
Ye fools that wear gay clothes love to be gap'd at,
What are you better when your end calls on you?
Will gold preserve ye from the grave? or jewells?
Get golden minds, and fling away your Trappings
Unto your bodies, minister warm rayments,
Wholsom and good; glitter within and spare not:
Let my Court have rich souls, their suits I weigh not:
And what are you that took such State upon ye?
Are ye a Prince?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: The Prince of Tailors, Sir,
We owe some money to him, and 't like your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: If it like him, would ye owde more, be modester,
And you lesse sawcy Sir: and leave this place:
Your pressing iron will make no perfect Courtier:
Go stitch at home, and cozen your poor neighbours,
Show such another pride, I'll have ye whipt for't,
And get worse clothes, these but proclaim your fellony.
And what's your paper?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I beseech you read it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What's here? the Count Otrante task'd for a base villany,
For stealing of a maid?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: The Count Otrante?
Is not the fellow mad Sir?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: No, no, my Lord,
I am in my wits, I am a labouring man,
And we have seldom leisure to run mad,
We have other businesse to employ our heads in,
We have little wit to lose too: if we complain,
And if a heavie lord lie on our shoulders,
Worse then a sack of meal, and oppresse our poverties,
We are mad straight, and whop'd, and tyde in fetters,
Able to make a horse mad as you use us,
You are mad for nothing, and no man dare proclaim it,
In you a wildnesse is a noble trick,
And cherishd in ye, and all men must love it:
Oppressions of all sorts, sit like new clothes,
Neatly and hansomly upon your Lordships:
And if we kick when your honours spur us,
We are knaves and Jades, and ready for the Justice.
I am a true Miller.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then thou art a wonder.

sp.speaker: 2 L.
sp.l: I know the man reputed for a good man
An honest and substantial fellow.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: He speaks sence,
And to the point: Greatnesse begets much rudenesse.
How dare you (Sirrha) 'gainst so main a person,
A man of so much Noble note and honour,
Put up this base complaint? Must every Pesant
Upon a sawcy will affront great Lords!
All fellows (Miller?)

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I have my reward, Sir,
I was told one greatnesse would protect another,
As beams support their fellowes; now I find it:
If 't please your Grace to have me hang'd, I am ready,
Tis but a Miller, and a Thief dispatch'd:
Though I steal bread, I steal no flesh to tempt me.
I have a wife, and 't please him to have her too,
With all my heart; 't will make my charge the lesse Sir,
She'll hold him play a while: I have a Boy too,
He is able to instruct his Honours hoggs,
Or rub his Horse-heels: when it please his Lordship
He may make him his slave too, or his bawd:
The boy is well bred, can exhort his Sister:
For me, the prison, or the Pillory,
To lose my goods, and have mine ears cropt off:
Whipt like a Topp, and have a paper stuck before me,
For abominable honestie to his owne daughter,
I can endure, Sir: the Miller has a stout heart,
Tough as his Toal-pin.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I suspect this shrewdly,
Is it his daughter that the people call
The Millers fair maid?

sp.speaker: 2 Lo.
sp.l: It should seem so Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Be sure you be i'th' right, Sirrha.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: If I be i'th' wrong Sir,
Be sure you hang me, I will ask no curtesie:
Your Grace may have a daughter, think of that Sir,
She may be fair, and she may be abused too:
A King is not exempted from these cases:
Stolne from your loving care.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I do much pity him.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: But heaven forbid she should be in that venture
That mine is in at this hour: I'll assure your Grace
The Lord wants a water-mill, & means to grind with her
Would I had his stones to set, I would fit him for it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Follow me (Miller) and let me talk with ye farther,
And keep this private all upon your loyalties:
To morrow morning, though I am now beyond him,
And the lesse lookt for, I'll break my fast with good Count.
No more, away, all to our sports, be silent. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What Grace shall I have now?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Choose thine owne grace,
And go to dinner when thou wilt, Vertigo,
We must needs follow the King.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: You heard the sentence.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: If you stay here
I'll send thee a shoulder of Venison:
Go home, go home, or if thou wilt disguise,
I'll help thee to a place to feed the dogs.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Or thou shalt be special Tailor to the Kings Monkey,
'Tis a fine place, we cannot stay.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: No money,
Nor no grace (Gentlemen?)

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: 'Tis top early Taylor.
The King has not broke his fast yet.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I shall look for ye
The next Terme, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Thou shalt not misse us:
Prethee provide some clothes, and dost thou hear Vertigo,
Commend me to thy wife: I want some shirts too.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I have Chambers for ye all.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: They are too musty,
When they are cleer wee'l come.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: I must be patient
And provident, I shall never get home els. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Prethee be wiser wench, thou canst not scape me,
Let me with love and gentlenesse enjoy that
That may be still preserv'd with love, and long'd for,
If violence lay rough hold, I shall hate thee,
And after I have enjoyd thy Maiden-head,
Thou wilt appear so stale and ugly to me
I shall despise thee, cast thee off.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.l: I pray ye, Sir,
Begin it now, and open your dores to me,
I do confesse I am ugly; Let me go, Sir:
A Gipsey-girl: Why would your Lordship touch me?
Fye, 'tis not noble: I am homely bred,
Course, and unfit for you: why do you flatter me?
There be young Ladies, many that will love ye,
That will dote on ye: you are a hansome Gentleman,
What will they say when once they know your quality?
A Lord, a Miller? take your Toal-dish with ye:
You that can deal with Gudgins, and course floure,
'Tis pitie you should taste what manchet means:
Is this fit Sir, for your repute and honour?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I'll love thee still.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You cannot, there's no sympathy
Between our births, our breeding, arts, conditions,
And where these are at difference, there's no liking:
This houre it may be I seem hansom to you,
And you are taken with variety
More then with beauty: to morrow when you have enjoy'd me,
Your heate and lust asswag'd, and come to examine
Out of cold and penitent condition
What you have done, whom you have shar'd your love with,
Made partner of your bed, how it will vex ye,
How you will curse the devil that betrayd ye:
And what shall become of me then?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Wilt thou hear me?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: As hastie as you were then to enjoy me,
As precious as this beauty shew'd unto ye,
You'll kick me out of dores, you will whore and ban me:
And if I prove with child with your fair issue,
Give me a pension of five pound a yeer
To breed your heir withall, and so good speed me.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I'll keep thee like a woman.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I'll keep my self Sir,
Keep my self honest Sir; there's the brave keeping:
If you will marry me.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Alas poor Florimell.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I do confesse I am too course and base Sir
To be your wife, and it is fit you scorn me,
Yet such as I have crown'd the lives of great ones:
To be your whore, I am sure I am too worthy,
(For by my troth Sir, I am truly honest)
And that's an honour equal to your greatnes.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I'll give thee what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Tempt me no more then:
Give me that peace, and then you give abundance,
I know ye do but try me, ye are noble,
All these are but to try my modestie,
If you should find me easie, and once coming,
I see your eies already how they would fright me:
I see your honest heart how it would swell
And burst it self into a grief against me:
Your tongue in noble anger, now, even now Sir,
Ready to rip my loose thoughts to the bottom,
And lay my shame unto my self, wide open:
You are a noble Lord: you pity poor maids,
The people are mistaken in your courses:
You, like a father, try'em to the uttermost.
As they do gold: you purge the drosse from them,
And make them shine.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: This cunning cannot help ye:
I love ye to enjoy ye: I have stolne ye
To enjoy ye now, not to be fool'd with circumstance,
Yeeld willingly, or else.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I will force ye.
I will not be delay'd, a poor base wench
That I in curtesie make offer to,
Argue with me?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Do not, you will lose your labour,
Do not (my Lord) it will become ye poorly
Your curtesie may do much on my nature,
For I am kind as you are, and as tender:
If you compell, I have my strengths to fly to,
My honest thoughts, and those are guards about me:
I can cry too, and noise enough I dare make,
And I have curses, that will call down thunder,
For all I am a poor wench, heaven will hear me:
My body you may force, but my will never;
And be sure I do not live if you do force me,
Or have no tongue to tell your beastly Story,
For if I have, and if there be a Justice.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Pray ye go in here: I'll calme my self for this time.
And be your friend again.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I am commanded. Exit.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: You cannot scape me, yet I must enjoy ye,
I'll lie with thy wit, though I misse thy honesty:
Is this a wench for a Boors hungry bosom?
A morsel for a Peasants base embraces?
And must I starve, and the meat in my mouth?
I'll none of that. Enter Gerasto.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: How now my Lord, how sped ye?
Have ye done the deed?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: No, pox upon't, she is honest.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Honest? what's that? you take her bare deniall,
Was there ever wench brought up in a mill, and honest?
That were a wonder worth a Chronicle,
Is your belief so large? what did she say to ye?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: She said her honesty was all her dowry,
And preach'd unto me, how unfit, and homely,
Nay how dishonourable it would seem in me
To act my will; popt me i'th mouth with modestie.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: What an impudent Quean was that? that's their trick ever.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: And then discours'd to me very learnedly
What fame and loud opinion would tell of me:
A wife she touch'd at.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Out upon her Varlet.
Was she so bold? these home spun things are devils,
They'll tell ye a thousand lies, if you'll beleeve'em;
And stand upon their honours like great Ladies,
They'll speak unhappily too: good words to cozen ye,
And outwardly seem Saints: they'll cry down-right also,
But 'tis for anger that you do not crush 'em.
Did she not talk of being with child?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: She toucht at it,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: The trick of an arrant whore to milk your Lordship
And then a pension nam'd?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: No, no, she scorn'd it:
I offer'd any thing, but she refus'd all,
Refus'd it with a confident hate.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: You thought so,
You should have taken her then, turn'd her, and tew'd her
I'th' strength of all her resolution, flattered her,
And shak't her stubborn will: she would have thank'd ye,
She would have lov'd ye infinitely, they must seem modest,
It is their parts: if you had plaid your part Sir.
And handled her as men do unmand Hawks,
Cast her, and malde her-up in good clean linnen:
And there have coyed her, you had caught her heart-strings
These tough Virginities they blow like white thornes
In Stormes and Tempests.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: She is beyond all this,
As cold, and harden'd, as the Virgin Crystal.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Oh force her, force her, Sir, she longs to be ravishd
Some have no pleasure but in violence;
To be torne in pieces is their paradise:
'Tis ordinary in our Country, Sir, to ravish all
They will not give a penny for their sport
Unlesse they be put to it, and terribly,
And then they swear they'll hang the man comes neer'em,
And swear it on his lips too.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: No, no forcing,
I have an other course, and I will follow it,
I command you, and do you command your fellows,
That when you see her next, disgrace, and scorn her,
Ill seem to put her out o'th' dores o'th' sodain
And leave her to conjecture, then seize on her
Away, be ready straight.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: We shall not fail, Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Florimell.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I am sure you have now consider'd
And like a wise wench weigh'd a friends displeasure,
Repented your prowd thoughts, and cast your scorn off.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: My Lord, I am not proud, I was never beautifull.
Nor scorn I any thing that's just and honest.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Come, to be short, can ye love yet? you told me
Kindnes would far compell ye: I am kind to ye,
And mean to exceed that way.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I told ye too, Sir,
As far as it agreed with modestie,
With honour, and with honesty I would yeeld to yee:
Good my Lord, take some other Theam: for Love,
Alas, I never knew yet what it meant,
And on the sudden Sir, to run through volumes
Of his most mystick art, 'tis most impossible;
Nay, to begin with lust, which is an Herisie,
A foul one too; to learn that in my childhoodâ–ª
O good my Lord.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: You will not out of this song,
Your modestie, and honestie, is that all?
I will not force ye.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ye are too noble, Sir.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Nor play the childish fool, and marry ye,
I am yet not mad.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: If ye did, men would imagine.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Nor will I woo ye at that infinite price
It may be you expect.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I expect your pardon,
And a discharge (my Lord) that's all I look for.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: No, nor fall sick for love.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: 'Tis a healthful year Sir.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Look ye, I'l turn ye out o'dores, and scorn ye.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Thank ye my Lord.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: A proud slight Peat I found ye,
A fool (it may be too.)

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: An honest woman,
Good my Lord think me.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: And a base I leave ye,
So fare-ye-well. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Blessing attend your Lordship;
This is hot love, that vanisheth like vapors;
His Ague's off, his burning fits are well quench'd,
I thank heaven for't: his men, they will not force me.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: What dost thou stay for? dost thou not know the way,
Thou base unprovident whore?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Good words, pray ye Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: Has my Lord smoak'd ye over, good wife Miller?
Is your Mill broken that you stand so uselesse?

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: An impudent Quean, upon my life she is unwholsome;
Some base discarded thing my Lord has found her,
He would not have turnd her off o'th' sudden else.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Now against every sack (my honest sweet-heart)
With every Sim and Smug.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I must be patient.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: And every greasie guest, and sweaty Rascall
For his Royal hire between his fingers, Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: I feare thou hast given my Lord theâ€” thou damn'd thing.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: I have seen her in the Stewes.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: The knave her father
Was Bawd to her there, and kept a Tipling house,
You must even to it again: a modest function.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: If ye had honesty, ye would not use me
Thus basely wretchedly, though your Lord bid ye,
But he that knows.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Away thou carted impudence,
You meat for every man: a little meal
Flung in your face, makes ye appear so proud.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: This is inhumane. Let these tears perswade you
If ye be men, to use a poor girle better:
I wrong not you, I am sure I call you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: What busines is here? away, are not you gone yet?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: My Lord, this is not well: although you hate me,
For what I know not: to let your people wrong me,
Wrong me maliciously, and call me

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Peace,
And mark me what we say advisedly;
Mark, as you love that that you call your credit;
Yeeld now, or you are undone: your good name's perish'd
Not all the world can buy your reputation;
Tis sunk for ever els, these peoples tongues will poison ye
Though you be white as innocence, they'll taint ye,
They will speak terrible and hideous things,
And people in this age are prone to credit,
They'll let fell nothing that may brand a woman,
Consider this, and then be wise and tremble:
Yeeld yet, and yet I'll save ye.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I'll show ye,
Their mouthes I'll seal up, they shall speak no more
But what is honourable and honest of ye,
And Saintlike they shall worship ye: they are mine,
And what I charge 'em Florimell.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I am ruind,
Heaven will regard me yet, they are barbarous wretches:
Let me not fall (my Lord.)

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: You shall not Florimell:
Mark how I'll work your peace, and how I honour ye.
Who waits there? come all in.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: Your pleasure Sir.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Who dare say this sweet beauty is not heavenly?
This virgin, the most pure, the most untainted,
The holiest thing?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: We know it (my dear Lord)
We are her slaves: and that proud impudence
That dares disparage her, this sword (my Lord.)

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.l: They are rascals, base, the sons of common women
That wrong this vertue, or dare owne a thought
But fair and honourable of her: when we slight her,
Hang us, or cut's in pieces: let's tug i'th' Gallies.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.l: Brand us for villains.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why sure I dream: these are all Saints.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Go, and live all her slaves.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.l: We are proud to do it. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: What think ye now? am not I able Florimell
Yet to preserve ye?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I am bound to your Lordship,
Ye are all honour, and good my Lord but grant me
Untill to morrow leave to weigh my Fortunes,
I'll give you a free answer, perhaps a pleasing,
Indeed I'll do the best I can to satisfie ye.

sp.speaker: Otr.
