sp.p: Take your good time, this kisse, till then farewell, Sweet. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: By all means discharge your follower.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If we can get him off: Sirrha Bustofa.
Thou must needs run back.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: But I must not unlesse you send
A Bier, or a Lictor at my back, I do not use to run
From my friends.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well, go will serve turne: I have forgot.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: What Sir,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: See if I can think on't now.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I know what 'tis now?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A Pistolet of that.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Done, you have forgot a device to send me away,
You are going a smocking perhaps.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: His owne, due, due i'faith Antonio,
The Pistolet's his owne.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I confesse it,
There 'tis: now if you could afford out of it
A reasonable excuse to mine Uncle.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Yes, I can:
But an excuse will not serve your turn: it must be a lie,
A full lie, 'twill do no good else: if you'll go to
The price of that?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is a lie dearer then an excuse?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Oh, treble; this is the price of an excuse: but a lye is two more:
Look how many foyles go to a fair fall, so many excuses to
A full lye, and lesse cannot serve your turn, let any Tailor
I'th' Towne make it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Wie, 'tis reasonable, give him his price:
Let it be large enough now.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I'll warrant you, cover him all over.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would have proof of one now.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: What? scale my invention before hand? you shall pardon
Me for that: well, I'll commend you to your Uncle, and
Tell him you'll be at home at supper with him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By no means, I cannot come to night (man)

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I know that too, you do not know a lye when you see it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Remember it must stretch for all night.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: I shall want stuffe, I doubt 'twill come to the other Pistolet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Well, lay out, you shall be no loser Sir.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: It must be faced, you know, there will be a yard of dissimulation
At least (City-measure) and cut upon an untroth or two: Lyned
With Fables, that must needs be, cold weather's coming, if it had
A galloon of hypocrisie, 't would do well: and hooked
Together with a couple of conceits,
That's necessity; well, I'll bring in my
Bill: I'll warrant you as fair a lye by that time I have done
With it, as any gentleman i'th' Town can swear too: if he
Would betray his Lord and Master. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So, so, this necessary trouble's over.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I would you had bought an excuse of him
Before he went: you'll want one for Ismenia.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tush, there needs none, there's no suspition yet,
And I'll be arm'd before the next encounter,
In a fast tye with my fair Isabel.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, you'll find your errand is before you now.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Oh Gentlemen, look to your selves, ye are
Men of another world else: your enemies are upon you;
The old house of the Bellides will fall upon your heads:
Signior Lisauro.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lisauro?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: And Don what call you him? he's a Gentleman:
Yet he has but a Yeomans name,
Don Tarso, Tarso, and a dozen at their heels.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lisauro, Tarso, nor a dozen more
Shall fright me from my ground, nor shun my path,
Let'em come on in their ablest fury.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis worthily resolved: I'll stand by you Sir,
This way, I am thy true friend.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I'll be gone Sir, that one may live to tell what's become of you.
Put up, put up, will you never learn to know a lye
From an Esop's fables? there's a taste for you now. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Look Sir, what time of day is it?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I know not, my eies go false, I dare not trust'em now,
I prethee tell me (Martin) if thou canst,
Is that Ismenia, or Isabella.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This is the Lady, forget not Isabella.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: If this face may be borrowed and lent out,
If it can shift shoulders, and take other tyres,
So, 'tis mine where ere I find it

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Be sudden: Exit Aminta.
I cannot hold out long.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Beleeve't she frowns.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Let it come, she cannot frown me off on't:
How prettily it wooes me to come neerer?
How do you (Lady) since yesterdaies pains?
Were you not weary? of my faith.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I think you were.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What Lady?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Weary of your faith, 'tis a burthen
That men faint under, though they bear little of it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So, this is to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You came home
In a fair hour I hope? Enter Aminta.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: From whence Sir?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Sir, there's a Gentlewoman without desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: They were pretty homely toyes: but your presence
Made them illustrious.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: My Cosen speaks to you.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: A Gentlewoman Sir, Isabella
She names her self.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So, so, it hits finely now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Name your self how you please: speak what you please,
I'll hear you cheerfully.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: You are not well,
Request her in: she may have more acquaintance
With his passions, and better cure for'em.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: She's nice in that (Madam) poor soul it seems
She's fearfull of your displeasure.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I'll quit her
From that presently, and bring her in my self. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How carelesly do you behave your self?
When you should call all your best faculties
To councell in you: how will you answer
The breach you made with fair Ismenia?
Have you forgot the retrograde vow you took
With her, that now is come in evidence?
You'll die upon your shame, you need no more
Enemies of the house, but the Lady now:
You shall have your dispatch.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Give me that face,
And I am satisfied upon whose shoulders
So ere it growes: Juno deliver us
Out of this amazement: Beseech you Goddesse
Tell us of our friends, how dos Ismenia?
And how does Isabella? both in good health
I hope, as you your self are.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I am at farthest
In my counterfeit: my Antonio
I have matter against you may need pardon,
As I must crave of you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Observe you Sir,
What evidence is come against me? what think you
The Hydra-headed Jury will say to't?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis I am foold,
My hopes are pour'd into the bottomles tube,
Tis labour for the house of Bellides:
I must not seem so yet: but in sooth (Lady)
Did you imagine your changeable face
Hid you from me? by this hand I knew you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I went by the face: and by these eies I
Might have been deceived.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: You might indeed (Antonio)
For this Gentleman did vow to Isabella,
That he it was that lov'd Ismenia,
And not Antonio?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Good, and was not that
A manifest confession that I knew you?
I else had been unjust unto my friend:
Twas well remembred, there I found you out
And speak your conscience now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But did he so protest?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Yes, I vow to you, had Antonio
Wedded Isabella, Ismenia
Had not been lost, there had been her lover.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why much good do you friend, take her to you:
I crave but one, here have I my wish full,
I am glad we shall be so neer Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Take both Sir, Juno to boote: three parts in one,
S. Hilarie blesse you, now oportunitie
Beware to meet with falshood, if thou canst
Shun it, my friends faith's turning from him.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Might I not justly accuse Antonio
For a love-wanderer? you know no other
But me, for another, and confesse troth now?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here was my guide, where ere I find this face,
I am a Lover, marry, I must not misse
This freckle then, I have the number of 'em,
Nor this dimple: not a silk from this brow,
I carry the full Idea ever with me;
If Nature can so punctually paralel,
I may be cozened.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Well, all this is even:
But now, to perfect all, our love must now
Come to our Enemies hands, where neither part
Will ever give consent to't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Most certain:
For which reason it must not be put to'em:
Have we not prevention in our owne hands.
Shall I walk by the tree? desire the fruit,
Yet be so nice to pull till I ask leave
Of the churlish Gardner, that will deny me?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: O Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis manners to fall to
When grace is said.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: That holy act 's to come.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You may ope an oyster or two before grace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are there not double vows, as valuable
And as well spoke as any Frier utters?
Heaven has heard all.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Yes: but stayes the blessing,
Till all dues be done: heaven is not serv'd by halfs.
Wee shall have ne'r a fathers blessing here,
Let us not lose the better, from above.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You take up weapons of unequal force,
It shows you cowardly: heark in your ear.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Have I lost all imployment? Would this proffer
Had been made to me, though I had paid it
With a reasonable pennance.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Have I past
All thy fore-lock (Time)? I'll stretch a long arm
But I'll catch hold again: Doe but look back
Over thy shoulder, and have a pull at thee.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: I hear you (Sir) nor can I hear too much
While you speak well: You know th' accustom'd place
Of our night parley: if you can ascend,
The window shall receive you. You may finde there
A corrupted Church-man to bid you welcome.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would meet no other man.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Aminta, you hear this.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: With joy (Madam) 'cause it pleases you.
It may be mine own case another time:
Now you go the right way: ask the Banes out,
Put it past father, or friends, to forbid it,
And then you're sure. Sir, your Hymen Taper
I'll light up for you: the window shall show you
The way to Sestos.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I'll venture drowning.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The Simile holds not; 'tis hanging rather.
You must ascend your Castle by a ladder;
To the foot I'll bring you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Leave mee to climb it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If I do turn you off?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Till night fare-well:
Then better.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Best it should be;
But peevish hatred keeps back that degree. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I never look'd so smooth as now I purpose:
And then beware: Knave is at worst of knave
When he smiles best, and the most seems to save. Exit.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: My mind's unquiet; while Antonio
My Nephew's abroad, my heart is not at home,
Only my fears stay with me; bad company;
But I cannot shift 'em off. This hatred
Betwixt the House of Bellides and us,
Is not fair war: 'tis civill, but uncivill.
We are neer neighbours, were of love as neer,
Till a crosse misconstruction ('twas no more
In conscience) put us so far asunder:
I would 'twere reconcil'd; it has lasted
Too many Sun-sets, if grace might moderate:
Man should not lose so many dayes of peace
To satisfie the anger of one minute.
I could repent it heartily. I sent
The knave to attend my Antonio too, Enter Bustofa.
Yet he returns no comfort to me neither.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: No: I must not.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Hah; hee's come.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I must not: 'twill breake his heart to hear it.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How? there's bad tidings: I must obscure & hear it;
He will not tell mee for breaking of my heart,
'Tis half split already.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: I have spi'd him: Now to knock down a Don with a lie, a silly harmlesse lie; 'twill be valiantly done, and nobly perhaps.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I cannot hear him now.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Oh the bloody dayes that wee live in; the envious, malitious, deadly dayes that we draw breath in!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Now I hear too loud.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: The children that never shall be born may rue it; for men that are slain now might have liv'd to have got children, that might have curs'd their fathers.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh, my posterity is ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Oh sweet Antonio.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh deer Antonio.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Yet it was nobly done of both parts: When hee and Lisauro met,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh, death has parted 'em.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Welcome my mortall foe (sayes one), Welcome my deadly enemy (sayes th'other:) off go their doublets, they in their shirts, and their swords stark naked; here lies Antonio, here lies Lisauro: hee comes upon him with an Embroccado, that hee puts by with a puncta reversa; Lisauro recoils mee two paces and some six inches back, takes his career, and then, oh.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Runs Antonio quite thorow,

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh villain.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Quite thorow between the arme and the body: so yet he had no hurt at that bout.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Goodnesse be praised.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: But then, at next encounter, he fetches me up Lisauro; Lisauro makes out a Long at him, which he thinking to be a Passado, Antonio's foot slipping: down: oh down.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: O now thou art lost.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Oh, but the quality of the thing: both Gentlemen, both Spanish Christians, yet one man to shed

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Say his enemies blood.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: His hair may come by divers casualties, though he never go into the field with his foe: but a man to lose nine ounces and two drams of blood at one wound, thirteen and a scruple at another, and to live till he die in cold blood: yet the Surgeon (that cur'd him) said, if Pia-mater had not been perish'd, he had bin a lives man til this day.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: There hee concludes he is gone.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: But all this is nothing: now I come to the point.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I the point, that's deadly: the ancient blow
Over the buckler ne'r went half so deep.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p:
Yet pitie bids mee keep in my charitie: for mee to pull an old mans ears from his head with telling of a Tale: oh fowle Tale! No, be silent Tale. Furthermore, there is the charge of Buriall; every one will cry Blacks, Blacks, that had but the least finger dipt in his blood, though ten degrees remov'd when 'twas done. Moreover,
the Surgeon (that made an end of him) will be paid: Sugar-plums and sweet breads; yet I say, the man may recover again, and die in his bed.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What motley stuffe is this? Sirrha, speak truth
What hath befallen my deer Antonio?
Restrain your pity in concealing it;
Tell mee the danger full; take off your care
Of my receiving it: kill me that way,
I'll forgive my death: what thou keepst back from truth
Thou shalt speak in pain; doe not look to find
A limb in his right place, a bone unbroke,
Nor so much flesh unbroil'd of all that mountain
As a worm might sup on; dispatch, or be dispatch'd.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Alas Sir, I know nothing, but that Anton. is a man of Gods making to this hour, 'tis not two since I left him so.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Where didst thou leave him?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: In the same clothes he had on when he went from you.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Does he live?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I saw him drink.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Is he not wounded?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: He may have a cut i'th' leg by this time; for Don Martin and he were at whole slashes.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Met he not with Lisauro?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I doe not know her.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Her? Lisauro is a man, as he is.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I saw ne'r a man like him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Didst thou not discourse a fight betwixt Ant. & Lis.?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: I to my self; I hope a man may give himself the lie if it please him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Didst thou lie then?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: As sure as you live now.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I live the happier by it: when will he return?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: That he sent me to tel you, within these ten daies at farthest.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Ten daies? he's not wont to be absent two.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Nor I think he wil not: he said he would be at home to morrow; but I love to speak within my compasse.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You shall speak within mine Sir, now. Within there:
Take this fellow into custodie, keep him safe
I charge you.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Safe? do you hear? take notice what plight you find me in, if there want but a collop or a steak o'me, look to't.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: If my nephew return not in his health to morrow,
Thou goest to th' Rack.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Let me go to th' manger first; I had rather eat oats then hay. Exeunt. Enter Bellides with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: By your leave, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: For ought I know yet, you are welcom Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Read that, and tell me so: or if thy spectacles be not easie,
Keep thy nose unsadled, and ope thine ears;
I can speak thee the contents, I made 'em;
'Tis a challenge, a fair one, I'll maintain 't:
I scorn to hire my Second to deliver 't,
I bring 't my self: Dost know me, Julio?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Bellides?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes: Is not thine hair on end now?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Somwhat amaz'd at thy rash hardines;
How durst thou come so neer thine enemie?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Durst?
I dare come neerer: thou'rt a fool, Julio.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Take it home to thee with a knave to boot.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Knave to thy teeth again: and all that's quit:
Give me not a fool more then I give thee,
Or if thou dost, look to hear on't again.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: What an encounter's this?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: A noble one:
My hand is to my words, thou hast it there,
There I do challenge thee, if thou dar'st be,
Good friends with me; or I'll proclaim thee coward.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Be friends with thee?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I'll shew thee reasons for't:
A pair of old coxcombs (now wee go together)
Such as should stand examples of discretion,
The rules of Grammar to unwilling youth
To take out lessons by; we that should check
And quench the raging fire in others bloods,
We strike the battell to destruction?
Read 'em the black art? and make 'em beleeve
It is divinitie? Heathens, are we not?
Speak thy conscience, how hast thou slept this month,
Since this Fiend haunted us?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Sure, some good Angell
Was with us both last night: speak thou truth now,
Was it not last nights motion?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Dost not think
I would not lay hold of it at first proffer?
Should I ne'r sleep again?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Take not all from me;
I'll tell the doctrine of my vision.
Say that Antonio (best of thy blood)
Or any one, the least allyed to thee,
Should be the prey unto Lisauro's sword,
Or any of the house of Bellides?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Mine was the just inversion: on, on.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: How would thine eys have emptied thee in sorrow,
And left the condiment of Nature drie?
Thy hands have turn'd rebellious to the balls,
And broke the glasses, with thine own curses
Have torn thy soul, left thee a Statue
To propagate thy next posterity.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Yes, and thou causer? so it said to me,
They fight but your mischiefs: the yong men were friends,
As is the life and blood coagulate
And curded in one body; but this is yours,
An inheritance that you have gatherd for 'em,
A Legacie of blood, to kill each other
Throughout your Generations. Was't not so?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Word for word.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Nay, I can go farther yet.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: 'Tis far enough; Let us attone it here.
And in a reconciled circle fold
Our friendship new again.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The signe's in Gemini,
An auspicious house, 't has joyn'd both ours again.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You cannot proclaim me coward now, Don Bellides

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: No: thou'rt a valiant fellow: so am I:
I'll fight with thee at this hug, to the last leg
I have to stand on, or breath or life left.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: This is the salt unto humanity,
And keeps it sweet.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Love! oh life stinks without it.
I can tell you news.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Good has long been wanting.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I do suspect, and I have some proof on't,
(So far as a Love Epistle comes to)
That Antonio (your nephew) and my daughter
Ismenia are very good friends before us.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: That were a double wall about our houses,
Which I could wish were builded.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I had it
From Antonio's Intimate, Don Martin:
And yet( me thought) it was no friendly part
To show it me.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Perhaps 't was his consent:
Lovers have policies as well as Statesmen:
They look not alwaies at the mark they aime at.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Wee'll take up cudgels, and have one bowt with'em,
They shall know nothing of this union:
And till they find themselves most desperate,
Succour shall never see'em.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: I'll take your part Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: It grows late; there's a happy day past us.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The example I hope to all behind it. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Stand fair, light of Love, which epithite and place
Adds to thee honour, to me it would be shame,
We must be weight in love, no grain too light;
Thou art the Land-mark, but if love be blind,
(As many that can see have so reported)
What benefit canst thou be to his darknesse?
Love is a Jewel (some say) inestimable,
But hung at the eare, deprives our owne sight,
And so it shines to others, not our selves.
I speak my skill, I have onely heard on't,
But I could wish a neerer document,
Alas, the ignorant desire to know:
Some say Love's but a toy, and with a but.
Now me thinks I should love it ne'r the worse,
A toy is harmelesse sure, and may be plaid with,
It seldom goes without his adjunct, pretty,
A pretty toy we say, 'tis meeter to joy too.
Well, here may be a mad night yet for all this,
Here's a Priest ready, and a Lady ready:
A chamber ready, and a bed ready,
'Tis then but making unready, and that's soone done:
My Lady is my Cosen; I, my self,
Which is neerest then? My desires are mine,
Say they be hers too, is't a hanging matter?
It may be ventur'd in a worser cause,
I must go question with my conscience:
I have the word; Centinel, do thou stand,
Thou shalt not need to call, I'll he at hand. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Are we not dog'd behind us, thinkst thou friend?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I heard not one bark, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There are that bite
And bark not (man) me-thought I spy'd two fellows
That through two streets together walk'd aloof,
And wore their eies suspiciously upon us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your Jealousie, nothing else; or such perhaps
As are afraid as much of us, who knows
But about the like busines? but for your fears sake
I'll advise and entreat one curtesie.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What's that friend?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will not be denyed, Sir,
Change your upper garments with me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It needs not.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I think so too, but I will have it so,
If you dare trust me with the better Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Nay then.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If there should be danger towards,
There will be the main mark I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here thou tak'st from me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Tush, the General
Must be safe, how ere the Battel goes:
See you the Beacon yonder?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, we are neer shore.

div.stage: Enter 2. Gentlemen with weapons drawn, they set upon Martin: Antonio pursues them out in rescue of Martin.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come, Land, land, you must clamber by the cliffe,
Here are no staires to rise by.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I, are you there? fight and Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Aminta above, and Martin return'd again, ascends.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Antonio?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes Ismenia.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Thine owne.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Quench the light, thine eies are guides illustrious.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: 'Tis necessary. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your legs have sav'd your lives, who ere you are,
Friend. Martin? where art thou? not hurt I hope:
Sure I was farthest in the pursuit of 'em:
My pleasures are forgotten through my fears:
The lights extinct, it was discreetly done:
They could not but have notice of the broile,
And fearing that might call up company,
Have carefully prevented, and closed up:
I do commend the heed; oh, but my friend,
I fear his hurt: friend? friend? it cannot be
So mortal, that I should lose thee quite, friend?
A groan, any thing that may discover thee:
Thou art not sunk so far, but I might hear thee:
I'll lay mine ear as low as thou canst fall:
Friend, Don Martin, I must answer for thee,
'Twas in my cause thou fell'st, if thou beest downe,
Such dangers stand betwixt us and our joyes,
That should we forethink ere we undertake,
Wee'ld sit at home, and save. What a night's here?
Purpos'd for so much joy, and now dispos'd
To so much wretchednes? I shall not rest in't:
If I had all my pleasures there within,
I should not entertain'em with a smile.
Good night to you: Mine will be black and sad,
A friend cannot, a woman may be bad. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: O thou false,

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Do your daringst, he's mine owne,
Soul and body mine, church and chamber mine,
Totally mine.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Darst thou face thy falshood?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Shall I not give a welcom to my wishes
Come home so sweetly: farewell your company
Till you be calmer woman. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Oh what a heap
Of misery has one night brought with it. Ent. Ant.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where is he? do you turn your shame from me?
You'r a blind Adultresse, you know you are.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: How's that Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Till I have vengeance,
Your sin's not pardonable: I'll have him,
If hell hide him not: y'have had your last of him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: What did he speak? I understood him not,
He calld me a foul name, it was not mine,
He took me for another sure.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Hah? are you there?
Where's your sweet heart? I have found you Traytor
To my house: wilt league with mine enemie?
You'll shed his blood, you'll say: hah? will you so?
And fight with your heels upwards? No Minion,
I have a husband for you, since y'are so ranck,
And such a husband as thou shalt like him,
Whether thou wilt or no: Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: It thunders with the storm now.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And to night
I'll have it dispatch'd: I'll make it sure, I,
By to morrow this time thy Maiden-head
Shall not be worth a Chicken, if it were
Knockt at an out-cry: go, I'll ha'ye before me:
Shough, shough, up to your coop, peay Hen.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Then I'll try my wings. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I, are you good at that? stop, stop thief, stop there. Exit.

div.head: Scaena secunda.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Now having leisure, and a happy wind,
Thou maist at pleasure cause the stones to grind,
Sayles spread, and grist here ready to be ground.
Fie, stand not idely, but let the Mill go round.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Why dost thou sing and dance thus? why so merry?
Why dost thou look so wantonly upon me?
And kisse my hands?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: If I were high enough,
I would kisse your lips too.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Do, this is some kindnes,
This tastes of willingnesse, nay, you may kisse
Still, but why o'th' sudden now does the fitt take ye,
Unoffered, or uncompell'd? why these sweet curtesies?
Even now you would have blush'd to death to kisse thus:
Prethee let me be prepar'd to meet thy kindnes,
I shall be unfurnish'd else to hold thee play, wench:
Stay now a little, and delay your blessings:
If this be love, me-thinks it is too violent:
If you repent you of your strictnesse to me,
It is so sudden, it wants circumstance.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Fy, how dull?

body.head: 2. Song.
body.l: How long shall I pine for love?
how long shall I sue in vaine?
How long like the Turtle-Dove
shall I heavily thus complain?
Shall the sayles of my love stand still?
Shall the grists of my hopes be unground?
Oh fie, oh fie, oh fie,
let the Mill, let the Mill go round.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Prethee be calme a little,
Thou mak'st me wonder, thou that wert so strange,
And read such pious rules to my behaviour
But yesternight: thou that wert made of modestie,
Shouldst in a few short minutes turn thus desperate.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: You are too cold.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I do confesse I freeze now,
I am another thing all over me:
It is my part to wooe, not to be courted:
Unfold this Riddle, 'tis to me a wonder,
That now o'th' instant ere I can expect,
Ere I can turn my thoughts, and think upon
A separation of your honest carriage
From the desires of youth, thus wantonly,
Thus beyond expectation.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I will tell ye,
And tell ye seriously, why I appear thus,
To hold ye no more ignorant and blinded,
I have no modestie, I am truly wanton:
I am that you look for Sir; now come up roundly:
If my strict face and counterfeited stalednesse
Could have won on ye, I had caught ye that way,
And you should ne'r have come to have known who hurt ye.
Prethee (sweet Count) be more familiar with me.
How ever we are open in our natures,
And apt to more desires then you dare meet with,
Yet we affect to lay the glosse of good on 't:
I saw you toucht not at the baite of chastity,
And that it grew distastefull to pour palate
To appear so holy, therefore I take my true shape:
Is your bed ready Sir? you shall quickly find me.

body.head: 3. Song.
body.l: On the bed Ile throw thee, throw thee downe;
Down being laid, shall we be afraid
to try the rights that belong to love?
No, no, there Ile wooe thee with a Crown,
crown our desires, kindle the fires,
when love requires we should wanton prove:
We'll kisse, we'll sport, we'll laugh, we'll play,
If thou com'st short, for thee Ile stay,
If thou unskilfull art the ground,
Ile kindly teach, we'll have the Mill go round.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Are ye no maid?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Alas (my Lord) no certain:
I am sorry you are so innocent to think so,
Is this an age for silly maids to thrive in?
It is so long too since I lost it Sir,
That I have no belief I ever was one:
What should you do with maiden-heads? you hate'em,
They are peevish pettish things, that hold no game up,
No pleasure neither, they are sport for Surgeons:
I'll warrant you I'll fit you beyond Maiden-head:
A fair and easie way men travel right in,
And with delight, discourse, and twenty pleasures,
They enjoy their journey; mad men creep through hedges.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I am metamorphosed: why do you appeare,
I conjure ye, beyond belief thus wanton?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Because I would give ye
Pleasure beyond belief.

body.head: 4. Song.
body.l: Think me still in my Fathers Mill,
where I have oft been found
a-thrown on my back, on a well-fill'd sack,
while the Mill has still gone round-a:
Prethee sirrha try thy skill,
and again let the mill go round-a.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Then you have traded?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Traded? how should I know else how to live Sir,
And how to satisfie such Lords as you are,
Our best guests, and our richest?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: How I shake now?
You take no base men?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Any that will offer,
All manner of men, and all Religions Sir,
We touch at in our time: all States and Ages,
We exempt none.

body.head: 5. Song.
body.l: The young one, the old one, the fearful, the bold one,
the lame one, though nere so unsound,
The Jew or the Turk, have leave for to work,
the whilest that the Mill goes round,

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: You are a common thing then.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No matter since you have your private pleasure,
And have it by an Artist excellent,
Whether I am thus, or thus, your men can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: My men? Defend me, how I freeze together,
And am on ice? do I bite at such an Orange
After my men? I am preferr'd.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Why stay ye?
Why do we talk my Lord, and lose our time?
Pleasure was made for lips, and sweet embraces,
Let Lawyers use their tongues: pardon me Modestie,
This desperate way must help, or I am miserable.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: She turns, and wipes her face, she weeps for certain,
Some new way now, she cannot be thus beastly,
She is too excellent fair to be thus impudent:
She knows the elements of common loosenesse,
The art of lewdnesse: that, that, that, how now, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: The King (and't please your Lordship) is alighted Close at the gate.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: The King?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: And calls for ye Sir.
Means to break-fast here too.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Then I am happy.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Stolne so suddenly? go lock her up,
Lock her up where the Courtiers may not see her,
Lock her up closely, sirrha, in my closet.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I will (my Lord) what does she yeeld yet? Exit.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Peace:
She is either a damnd divel, or an Angel,
No noise (upon your life Dame) but all silence.

div.stage: Enter King, Lords, Vertigo, Lisauro, Terso.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Your Majesty heaps too much honour on me,
With such delight to view each several corner
Of a rude pile: there's no proportion in't, Sir.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Me-thinks 'tis hansom, and the rooms along
Are neat, and well contriv'd: the Gallery
Stands pleasantly and sweet: what rooms are these?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: They are sluttish ones.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay, I must see.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Pray ye do Sir,
They are lodging-chambers over a homely garden.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Fit still, and hansom; very well: and those?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.p: Those lead to the other side o'th' house, and't like ye.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Let me see those.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Ye may, the dores are open.
What should this view mean? I am half suspicious.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This little Room?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Tis mean: a place for trash Sir,
For rubbish of the house.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I would see this too:
I will see all.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I beseech your Majesty,
The savour of it, and the course appearance.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis not so bad, you would not offend your house with it,
Come, let me see.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Faith Sir,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I'faith I will see.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: My Groom has the key Sir, and 'tis ten to one

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But I will see it: force the lock (my Lords)
There be smithes enough to mend it: I perceive
You keep some rare things here, you would not show Sir.

sp.speaker: Ter.
sp.l: Here's a fair maid indeed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: By my faith is she
A hansom girle: come forward, do not fear wench.
I marry, here's a treasure worth concealing:
Call in the Miller.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Then I am discovered.
I confesse all before the Miller comes Sir,
'Twas but intention, from all act I am cleer yet.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Is this your daughter?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes, and 't please your Highnesse.
This is the shape of her, for her substance Sir,
Whether she be now honourable or dishonourable:
Whether she be a white-rose, or a canker, is the question:
I thank my Lord, he made bold with my Philly,
If she be for your pace, you had best preserve her Sir,
She is tender mouthed, let her be broken hansomly.
Maid, were you stolne?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I went not willingly,
And 't please your Grace, I was never bred so boldly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How has he us'd ye?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Yet Sir, very nobly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Be sure ye tell truth, and be sure (my Lord)
You have not wrongd her: if ye have, I tell ye
You have lost me, and your self too: speak again (wench)

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: He has not wrong'd me, Sir; I am yet a maid:
By all that's white and innocent, I am Sir,
Onely I sufferd under strong temptations
The heat of youth; but heaven deliverd me.
My Lord, I am no whore, for all I faign'd it,
And faign'd it cunningly, and made ye loath me:
'Twas time to out-do you: I had been robd else,
I had been miserable, but I forgive ye.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What recompence for this?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: A great one Sir,
First a repentance, and a hearty one.
Forgive me Sweet.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: I do my Lord.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: I thank ye;
The next take this, and these: all I have Florimell.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: No good my Lord, these often corrupt maidens:
I dare not touch at these; they are lime for Virgins;
But if you'll give me.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Any thing in my power.
Or in my purchase.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Take heed (noble Sir)
You'll make me a bold asker.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Aske me freely.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Ask you? I do ask you, and I deserve ye,
I have kept ye from a crying sin would damne ye
To Men and Time: I have preserv'd your credit,
That would have died to all posterity:
Curses of maids shall never now afflict ye,
Nor Parents bitter tears make your name barren:
If he deserves well that redeems his Countrey,
And as a Patriot be remembred nobly,
Nay, set the highest: may not I be worthy
To be your friend, that have preservd your honor?

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: You are, and thus I take ye: thus I seal ye
Mine owne, and onely mine.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Count, she deserves ye,
And let it be my happines to give ye,
I have given a vertuous maid, now I dare say it,
'Tis more then blood; I'll pay her portion Sir,
And't shall be worthy you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I'll sell my Mill,
I'll pay some too: I'll pay the Fidlers,
And we'll have all i' th' Country at this wedding,
Pray let me give her too, here my Lord take her,
Take her with all my heart, and kisse her freely,
Would I could give you all this hand has stolne too,
In portion with her, 'twould make her a little whiter.
The wind blows fair now, get me a young Miller.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Shee must have new clothes.

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Yes marry must she.
If't please ye (Madam) let me see the state of you body.
I'll fit you instantly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Art not thou gone yet?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: And 't please your Grace, a gown, a handsome gown now,
An orient gown.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Nay, take thy pleasure of her.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Of cloth of Tissew I can fit ye (Madam)
My Lords, stand out o'th' light, a curious body,
The neatest body in Spain this day: w embroidred flowrs,
A clinquant Petticoat of some rich stuffe,
To catch the eye: I have a thousand fashions.
O sleeve, O sleeve: I'll study all night (Madam)
To magnifie your sleeve.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Do, superstitious Tailor,
When yee have more time.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.l: Make me no more then woman,
And I am thine.

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: Sir, haply my Wardrobe with your help
May fit her instantly: will you try her?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: If I fit her not, your Wardrobe cannot.
But if the fashion be not there, you marre her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is my offence so great, ere I be convict,
To be torn with Rascals? If it be Law,
Let 'm be wild horses, rather then these.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: This is a man suspected of murder, if it please your Grace.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: It pleases me not (friend). But who suspects him?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: We that are your Highnes extraordinary officers,
We that have taken our oaths to maintain you in peace.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Twill be a great charge to you.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: 'Tis a great charge indeed; but then we call our neighbours to help us. This Gentleman and another were fallen out (yet that's more then I am able to say, for I heard no words between 'em, but what their weapons spoke, Clash, and Clatter) which we seeing, came with our Bils of government, and first knock'd down their weapons, and then the men.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: And this you did to keep the peace?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Yes, and 't like your Grace, we knock'd 'em down to keep the peace: this we laid hold on, the other we set in the stocks. That I could do by mine own power, without your Majestie. Enter Aminta.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How so, Sir?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: I am a Shoo-maker by my Trade.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Oh my husband!
Why stands my husband as a man endanger'd?
Restore him me, as you are mercifull,
I'll answer for him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What woman's this? what husband? hold thy bawling,
I know thee for no wife.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: You married me last night.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou lyest: I neither was in Church nor house
Last night, nor saw I thee: a thing that was my friend,
I scorne to name now, was with Ismenia,
Like a thief, and there he violated
A sacred trust. This thou maist know (Aminta).

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Are not you hee?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No; nor a friend of his:
Would I had kill'd him: I hope I have.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: That was my husband (Royall Sir) that man,
That excellent man. Enter Bellides.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That villain, that theefe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Have I caught you Sir? well overtaken.
This is mine enemie: pardon (my Soveraigne).

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Good charitie, to crave pardon for your enemie.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Mine own pardon (Sir) for my joyes rudenesse:
In what place better could I meet my foe,
And both of us so well provided too?
Hee with some black blood-thirstie crime upon him,
That (ere the horse-leech burst) will suck him dry:
I with a second accusation,
Enough to break his neck, if need should be,
And then to have even Justice self to right us:
How should I make my joyes a little civill,
They might not keep this noyse?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Here is some hope.
Should the ax be dull, the halter's preparing.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What's your accusation, Sir? We have heard the former. Enter Julio.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Mine (My Lord)? a strong one.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: A false one, Sir.
At least malicious: an evidence
Of hatred and despight: He would accuse
My poor kinsman of that he never dream'd of,
Nor waking saw; the stealing of his daughter,
She whom, I know, he would not look upon.
Speak Antonio, Didst thou ever see her?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes Sir, I have seen her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ah ha, friend Julio.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: He might, but how? with an unheedfull eye,
An accidentall view, as men see multitudes
That the next day dare not precisely say
They saw that face, or that amongst 'm all,
Didst thou so look on her?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Guilty, guilty:
His looks hang themselves.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your patience (Gentleman).
I pray you tell me if I be in errour,
I may speak often when I should but hear:
This is some Show you would present us with,
And I do interrupt it: Pray you speak,
(It seems no more) Is 't any thing but a Show?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: My Lord, this Gentlewoman can show you all,
So could my daughter too, if shee were here;
By this time they are both immodest enough:
Shee's fled me, and I accuse this thief for't.
Don Martin, his own friend 's my testimony:
A practis'd night-work.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: That Martin's the other
In your custodie; he was forgotten:
Fetch him hither.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Wee'll bring the Stocks and all else, and't please your Grace. Enter Bustofa and Ismenia.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: That man's my husband certain, instead of this:
Both would have deceiv'd, and both beguil'd.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Soh hoh, Miller, Miller, look out Miller: is there nere a Miller amongst you here, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Tir.
sp.l: Yes Sir, here is a Miller amongst Gentlemen,
A Gentleman Miller.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: I should not be far off then; there went but a pair of sheers and a bodkin between us. Will you to work Miller? Here's a maid has a sack full of newes for you, shall your stones walk? will you grind Miller?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This your son, Franio?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: My ungratious, my disobedient,
My unnaturall, my rebell son (my Lord).

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Fie, your hopper runs over, Miller.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: This villain (of my own flesh & blood) was accessary
To the stealing of my daughter.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Oh mountain,
Shalt thou call a molehill a scab upon the face
Of the earth? Though a man be a thief, shall a Miller call
Him so? Oh egregious!

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Remember Sirha, who you speak before.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I speak before a Miller,
A thief in grain; for he steals corn: He that steals
A wench, is a true man to him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Can you prove that? you may help another cause that was in pleading.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I'll prove it strongly.
He that steals corn, steals the bread of the Common-wealth;
He that steals a wench, steals but the flesh.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And how is the bread stealing more criminall then the flesh?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Hee that steals bread, steals that which is lawfull every day:
He that steals flesh, steals nothing from the fasting day:
Ergo, To steal the bread is the arranter theft.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This is to some purpose.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Again, He that steals flesh, steals for his own belly full:
He that steals bread, robs the guts of others:
Ergo, The arranter theef the bread-stealer.
sp.p: Again, He that steals flesh, steals once, and gives over; yes, and often payes for it: the other steals every day, without satisfaction. To conclude, Bread-stealing is the more capitall crime: for what he steals hee puts it in at the head: hee that steals flesh (as the Dutch Author sayes) puts it in at the foot, (the lower member.) Will you go as you are now, Miller?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: How has this satisfied you, Don Bellides?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Nothing (my Lord,) my cause is serious.
I claim a daughter from that loving theefe there.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I would I had her for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ah ha, Julio.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: How said you (Antonio)? Wish you you had his daughter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: With my soul I wish her; and my body
Shall perish, but I'll enjoy my souls wish.
I would have slain my friend for his deceit,
But I do find his own deceit hath paid him.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Will you vex my soul forth? no other choice
But where my hate is rooted? Come hither Girl,
Whose pretty maid art thou?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: The child of a poor man, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: The better for it. With my Soveraigns leave,
I'll wed thee to this man, will hee, nill he.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Pardon me, Sir, I'll be no Love enforcer:
I use no power of mine unto those ends.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Wilt thou have him?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Not unlesse he love me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I do love thee: Farewell all other Beauties:
I settle here: You are Ismenia.

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: The same I was: better nor worse (Antonio)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I shall have your consent here, I'm sure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: With all my heart, Sir. Nay, if you accept it,
I'll do this kindnesse to mine enemie,
And give her as a Father.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Shee'll thank you as a Daughter.
Will you not, Ismenia?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: How? Ismenia?

sp.speaker: Ism.
sp.l: Your daughter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Beleeu't
sp.l: ssiPoble? Away you feeble witted things,
You thought you had caught the old ones: You wade, you wade
In shallow fords: Wee can swim, we: look here,
We made the match: we are all friends, good friends;
Thin, thin: why the fool knew all this, this fool.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Keep that to your self, Sir; What I knew I knew: This Sack is a witnesse. Miller, this is not for your thumming. Here's gold lace: you may see her in her holliday clothes if you will; I was her ward-robe-man.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You beguil'd me well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Did you speak to me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: It might seem to you (Martin), your conscience
Has quick ears.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My sight was a little dim i'th' dark, indeed,
So was my feeling cozen'd; yet I'm content:
I am the better understander now,
I know my wife wants nothing of a woman;
There y'are my Junior.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You are not hurt?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not shrewdly hurt; I have good flesh to heal, you see,
Good round flesh: these cherries wil be worth chopping,
Crack stones and all; I should not give much to boot
To ride in your new, and you in my old ones now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You mistake the weapon: are you not hurt?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A little scratch: but I shal claw it off wel enough.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: I can no longer own what is not mine
With a free conscience: My Liege, your pardon.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For what? Who knows this woman?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I best (my Lord),
I have been acquainted with her these fortie Summers,
And as many Winters, were it Spring agen;
She's like the Gout, I can get no cure for her.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Oh, your wife, Franio?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: 'Tis oh my wife indeed (my Lord,)
A painfull stitch to my side; would it were pick'd out.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well Sir, your silence.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Wil you be older and older every day then other? the longer you live the older still? Must his Majestie command your silence ere you'l hold your tongue?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your reprehension runs into the same fault:
Pray Sir, will you be silent.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I have told him of this before now (my Liege) but
Age will have his course, and his weaknesses,

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Good Sir, your forbearance.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: And his frailties, and his follies (as I may say) that cannot hold his tongue ere he be bidden.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Why Sirha?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: But I beleeve your Majestie will not be long troubled with him: I hope that woman has something to confesse will hang 'em both.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Sirha, you'll pull your destinie upon you
If you cease not the sooner.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Nay, I have done, my Liege; yet it grieves me that I should call that man Father, that should be so shamelesse, that being commanded to hold his tongue.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: To th' Porters Lodge with him.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: I thank your Grace, I have a friend there.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Speak woman, if any interruption meet thee more,
It shall be punish'd sharply.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Good my Liege (I dare not)
Ask you the question why that old man weeps.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Who? Count Julio? I observ'd it not.
You hear the question Sir, will you give the cause?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh my Lord, it hardly will get passage,
It is a sorrow of that greatnesse grown,
'Lesse it dissolve in tears, and come by parcels.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: I'll help you Sir, in the delivery,
And bring you forth a joy. You lost a daughter.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: 'Twas that recounted thought brought forth these sorrows.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Shee's found again. Know you this mantle Sir?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Hah?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Nay leave your wonder, I'll explain it to you.
This did enwrap your childe (whom ever since
I have call'd mine) when Nurse Amaranta
In a remove from Mora to Corduba
Was seiz'd on by a fierce and hungry Bear,
She was the Ravins prey, as heaven so would,
He with his booty fill'd, forsook the babe:
All this was in my sight: and so long I saw,
Untill the cruell creature left my sight,
At which advantage I adventur'd me
To rescue the sweet Lamb: I did it Sir,
And ever since I have kept back your joy,
And made it mine: but age hath wearied me,
And bids me back restore unto the owner
What I unjustly kept these fourteen yeers.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Oh, thou hast ta'n so many yeers from mee,
And made me young, as was her birth-day to me.
Oh (good my Liege) give my joyes a pardon,
I must go powre a blessing on my child,
Which here would be too rude and troublesome. Exit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Franio, you knew this before.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Oh, oh; Item for you Miller.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I did (my Liege) I must confesse I did,
And I confesse, I ne'r would have confess'd,
Had not that womans tongue begun to me:
We poor ones love, and would have comforts, Sir,
As well as great: this is no strange fault, Sir,
There's many men keep other mens children
As though they were their own.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: It may stretch farther yet, I beseech you (my Liege) let this woman be a little farther examin'd; let the words of her conscience be search'd. I would know how she came by me: I am a lost childe, if I be theirs: though I have been brought up in a mill, yet I had ever a minde( me thought) to be a greater man.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Shee will resolve you sure.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: I, I Boy: thou art mine own flesh and blood,
Born of mine own body.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: 'Tis very unlikely that such a body should bear me; There's no trust in these millers. Woman, tell the truth: my father shall forgive thee, whatsoever he was, were hee Knight, Squire, or Captain; lesse he should not be.

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Thou art mine own child, Boy.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: And was the Miller my Father?

sp.speaker: Gill.
sp.l: Wouldst thou make thy mother a whore, Knave?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: I, if she make me a Bastard. The rack must make her confesse (my Lord) I shall never come to know who I am else. I have a worshipfull mind in mee sure: mee thinks I do scorn poor folks.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Here comes the brightest glory of the day:
Love yoak'd with love, the best equality,
Without the levell of estate or person.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You both shall be rewarded bountifully,
Wee'll be a-kin too; Brother and Sister
shall be chang'd with us ever.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.p: Thank you (Unkle) my sister is my cosen yet at the last cast: Farewell sister foster. If I had known the Civill law would have allowed it, thou hadst had another manner of husband then thou hast: but much good doe thee; I'll dance at thy wedding, kisse the Bride, and so.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: Why, how now sirha?

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: 'Tis lawfull now, she's none of my Sister.
It was a Miller and a Lord
That had a scabberd and a sword,
He put it up in the Country word
The Miller and his daughter.
Shee has a face, and she can sing,
Shee has a Grace, and she can spring,
Shee has a place with another thing
Tradoodle.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A knavish Brother of yours (my Lord).

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: would I were acquainted with your Tailor (Noble Brother).

sp.speaker: Otr.
sp.l: You may, there he is a mine, newly entertain'd.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: If you have any work for me, I can fit you Sir,
I fitted the Lady.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: My Sister (Tailor,) what fits her wil hardly fit me.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Who fits her may fit you Sir, the Tailor can do both.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: You have a true yard (Tailor.)

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Ne'r a whit too long, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Bust.
sp.l: Then (Tailor) march with me away,
I scorn these robes, I must be gay,
My Noble Brother, he shall pay
Tom Tailor. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Your recovered friendships are sound, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: At heart, at heart (my Lord) the worm shall not
Beyond many ages find a breach to enter at.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: These Lovers unities I will not doubt of:
How happy have you made our Progresse then,
To be the witnesse of such fair Accords?
Come, now we'll eat with you (my Lord Otrante,)
'Tis a charge sav'd: You must not grudge your guest,
'Tis both my Welcome, and your Wedding-Feast.
